title: biased unfunny smug ian hislop
story: Same captains, same hosts and same agenda.All it’s really lost, since the arrival of Covid-, is the studio audience, so instead of the applause, which used to mask many of the show’s obvious flaws, you now just hear five guffaws of self-congratulation from the lists, who may be filmed in isolation but are definitely all still living in the same London media bubble.It reached a crescendo, on Friday night, when Hislop, Merton, host Martin Clunes and regular list Janet Street-Porter were joined by Fin Taylor, from The Mash Report, because you just can’t have enough left-of-centre public schoolboys on this show, can you First deserving target for the night was very obviously going to be government adviser Dominic Cummings, who asked for the attention the moment he set-off on that ridiculous “ersion” to Barnard Castle.It was no surprise at all, then, when Hislop, chins quivering with confected outrage, opened the show by announcing: “I’ve been trying hard not to be cross all week.”Cross  He looked like a man who couldn’t contain his happiness, so out it came in gleeful fits and starts, until he eventually concluded: “Mister Cummings, everyone is so annoyed with you and wants you to resign, you complete and utter fraud.”Under normal circumstances, of course, I’d be wondering when exactly Ian Hislop was told to file comments on behalf of “everyone”.On this occasion, though, I think it’s pretty clear he assumed the responsibility at the same meeting where Newsnight’s Emily Maitlis was appointed spokesman for “the country”.Both talked with a clear sense of entitlement and no deference to the BBC’s own rules.The one key dference was, Emily Maitlis’s outburst was over pretty quickly.After about  minutes of Friday’s kangaroo court, it was quite clear George Floyd, America’s riots and China’s incursion into Hong Kong weren’t getting a look-in. The entire show was given over to Dominic Cummings.None of it was funny, obviously. Have I Got News For You hasn’t been funny in years.What still slightly surprised me, however, was that they chose to believe every single negative story the Press had written about him, last week, including some of the stuff which, like the police hauling him in for questioning, was clearly a load of cobblers.Quite a contrast to the previous week when, based on one Mail on Sunday story, host Charlie Brooker asked: “Why do you think the Press has got it in for Keir Starmer ”Apart from the fact the entire Press hasn’t got it in for him , it’s the question’s assumption that gives the game away here.The BBC and HIGNFY have already decided Keir Starmer is great and will not tolerate any dissent.I’m grateful for it anyway, as it shines a light on the dumb equation that’s come to govern this show: Have I Got News For You believes every bad word written about the Government and disbelieves every bad word written of the Opposition.If a satirical show is stupid enough to put every politician it agrees withoff limits, it’s guaranteed to fail, which is why HIGNFY’s time has come and long gone and it deserves to be jettisoned as quickly as possible.For that to happen, though, the BBC would need to dismount its high horse, admit errors and bias and change its political culture entirely.So expect it to keep coming back. Same captains, same hosts, same agenda.Repeat ’til fade.Fin Taylor: “How does a four-year-old hold his urine in for five hours ”He watches ten back-to-back episodes of Have I Got News For You.Unlikely, Chubadub.WELL, there goes another eight minor celebrities who won’t be retiring to India any time soon.The fourth time it’s happened on BBC’s The Real Marigold Hotel, with a fth, sixth and seventh intake no doubt in the pipeline, given we’re all picking up the bill.Apart from the pretence, though, I don’t bear them too much resentment, as this year’s holidaymakers were outstandingly good value for money, entertainment-wise.Personal favourites were: Duncan Bannatyne who, as only a Glaswegian can, turned yoga into a martial art, the charming Henry Blofeld, who waxed lyrical about everything, from his morning cup of coffee onwards, raising expectations about the day ahead.And deadpan Yorkshireman Paul Chuckle, who would immediately flatten the mood with killer observations like: “The French quarter where we’re staying is, very obviously, French. They have croissants.”The real grit in the oyster, however, was actress Britt Ekland who, apart from those moments when she was chasing after multi-millionaire Duncan, always gave the impression she’d rather set fire to her own Wicker Man than spend one more second in India.Would she finally be converted to the idea, the last episode of the series asked, by spending a night at a luxury retirement complex, in the foothills of the Himalayas, with Henry Blofeld and Paul Chuckle Well, Britt arrived like a dry cough in the morning, but  hours later . . .“This is my ultimate hell. I’m horried by the thought of coming to live here. I had nightmares you all left me and this is le.”BRITAIN’S Got Talent’s refreshment break, Simon Cowell: “Can I have some tea and a ginger shot ”WITH Celebrity SAS: Who Dares Wins finished, the title of “Best show on TV” was vacant for exactly  hours and two minutes before it was grabbed by Special Agent Doug Mathews on behalf of the Sky Documentaries channel.The breakout star and charismatic driving force behind McMillion, which begins with a single tip-off and post-it note: “McDonald’s Monopoly fraud.”Six hours later, we learn one bad apple, called “Uncle Jerry”, has distributed million of prize money to a cast of friends, family and Mafia acquaintances who are the very stuff of a dramatist’s dreams and all complete naturals in front of the camera.Some you hate at the beginning you’ll love by the end. Some you like at the start, you’ll probably learn to forgive as the final credits roll. They are the best and worst of America, with the same human frailties as us all.And yes, technically McMillion is probably one episode too long, but it’s all made worthwhile by the greatest single pay-off I’ve ever seen on a documentary series.McMillion, Sky Documentaries, Wednesday, pm.I’m lovin’ it.  The Last Leg’s Adam Hills trying to convey compassion for all coronavirus victims three weeks after he guffawed at the idea of Boris Johnson dying from the illness.Alan Carr’s right-on version of Play Your Cards Right removing the Dolly Dealers.This Morning’s Eamonn Holmes asking some pixie-chasing Irish nut: “What does lockdown mean for Leprechauns ” .And Springwatch presenter Steve Backshall telling us: “Some of the river rats around here have to be seen to be believed. I mean, honestly, they look like Gillian’s beavers. They’re absolutely massive.” News which left me far more worried about Gillian than the river rats.Who said the following, last week. “I would guess it’s somewhere between  to a thousand pounds. It was the shape of a human, very large and incredibly thick.”A Eyewitness Derek Randles on the History Channel’s Bigfoot Files B Narrator Angus Deayton on Gemma Collins: Diva On Lockdown THE joint winners of Channel ’s Britain’s Best Parent were declared to be the last seven couples, in the country, who’ve given their children proper names instead of making them sound like pet rabbits, or something off the Dulux colour chart.Not in the broadcast version, obviously. title: emily maitlis shrugs bbc bias newsnight cummings
story: EMILY Maitlis fronted BBCs Newsnight tonight for the first time since she delivered a critical monologue about Boris Johnsons top aide.The presenter, who began last weeks show by stating that Dominic Cummings had broken lockdown rules and blasted the PMs blind loyalty, shrugged off claims shed been biased and didnt address the controversy at all.The programme this week looked at ongoing riots in the U.S. at the death of unarmed black man George Floyd.Maitlis made no further comment about her speech from last week.The BBC apologised the day after Maitlis tore into Cummings, saying her introduction did not meet impartiality standards.It added: Staff have been reminded of the guidelines.Editor Katie Razzall replaced her during the programme last Wednesday, with Maitlis saying she had asked for the night off.The Beeb has received more than , complaints in the week after the presenter criticised Cummings and the PM at the start of Tuesdays show.However, many are reportedly not about the presenters comments, and a source told the Daily Mail that some , were about the treatment of Maitlis.In her introduction to the BBC current affairs programme she said: Dominic Cummings broke the rules, the country can see that and its shocked the government cannot.She added that Cummings was the man, remember, who always got the public mood, he tagged the lazy label of elite on those who disagreed.The presenter was publicly reprimanded by bosses the next day for overstepping the mark.In a statement the corporation said: Newsnight risked giving the perception that the BBC was taking sides — or that the introduction constituted the presenter’s opinions, rather than a summary of the journalism which would follow.

title: test travellers airports opinion
story: Together with the staff, they provide the atmosphere, the le, the vitality.I started in the hospitality industry aged just  and it pains me to see the lobbies, restaurants and bars empty.Lockdown has been devastating for the tourism industry and I fear many businesses will not survive.For  years tourism has been part of my le and I have seen tremendous strides in Britain.We have world-class places to stay and to eat, earning the country a great reputation across the globe.But people from abroad will not be able to enjoy all we have to offerthe Government’s two-week travel quarantine starts next Monday.Under this restriction, anyone arriving in Britain will have to remain at the same address for two weeks.Spot-checks will be carried out to ensure any new arrivals are complying with isolation and fines will be imposed on those who flout it.No one coming here on ­holiday or on a short business trip is going to want to have to stay at one address for a ­fortnight after landing.It is to all intents and purposes a UK travel ban.This is why, along with  other travel companies, I have written to the Home Secretary, Priti Patel, calling for a ­dferent approach.The suggestion of “air bridges” would be a more sensible first step.Under this proposal, there would be agreements between Britain and other nations that are past their infection peak, which would allow ­people to move freely on arrival.In continental Europe, many countries are opening up to each other while blocking ­travellers from nations where they feel infection rates are still too high.Nations such as Denmark, which imposed a ban on ­people entering their country at the start of the pandemic, now let in a small number of other nationalities.When the infection rate here was high, we didn’t impose ­quarantines on people coming in from abroad. Yet now the rate is going down we are going to start doing so.This will seem perverse to the millions of us who have complied with ­lockdown laws while seeing planes arrive from highly infected nations.While we are effectively ­closing our borders, other nations are loosening their restrictions and opening up their markets to foreign travel.Many British companies have offices and subsidiaries overseas but the bosses of those firms won’t be able to visit their foreign-based business centres because they will face a two-week quarantine upon their .It gives totally the wrong impression to the world.The Prime Minister, Boris Johnson, had rightly ­campaigned for Brexit on the basis that Britain would be an outward-looking nation. That won’t be possible with international travel curtailed.Travellers will want to be reassured that airlines are ­taking measures to counter the spread of the virus, so ­temperature checks could be put into place at UK airports.That would tell the authorities which passengers have symptoms of the virus.It would be better than the two-week quarantine, which would only prolong a terrible ­nightmare for the British ­tourism industry upon which so many livelihoods depend. Around  per cent of the ­British workforce — four ­million people — have jobs either in or linked to tourism in this country.The industry is worth £billion to the economy but since lockdown it has stalled.The winter months are quiet, the spring has been spent in lockdown and the summer months are the most crucial.When the Government’s­ ­furlough scheme comes to an end, businesses will face some very tough ­choices.I am concerned about my ,-strong workforce and the last thing I would want to do is lay off staff. But I have got £.million going out the window every month due to lockdown.There are many businesses in this country that will not be able to weather the storm.Tourist destinations across the country, such as the Cotswolds and Bronte country in West Yorkshire, rely heavily on foreign visitors.At my London hotels, more than  per cent of the ­business comes from overseas.To make matters worse, while most European countries — including Italy — have reduced the two-metre social distancing rule to one metre, just about making operating possible, we continue to persist with the two-metre ruling.How can you go to a restaurant where everyone will be two metres apart  How will staff serve you at a distance Of course, every Covid- death we have seen is a ­tragedy and my heart goes out to the families of the victims.But the reality of the disease is that for the majority of the population, the virus is not deadly unless there are underlying health issues.I am  and had three bad weeks with the virus — a week of high temperature, a week of gradually losing the symptoms and a third week where I was like a wet rag.At my age, it takes four or five weeks to properly recover from it.We must not lose sight of the number of livelihoods that have already been seriously damaged and the millions of people who will find themselves out of jobs at the end of lockdown.For the tourism industry, which has already been brought to a standstill, the two-week quarantine would be the final nail in the coffin.Let’s keep Britain open, so there is hope for the future.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: government spending furlough 1970s coronavirus
story: THE most extraordinary chapter in the story of modern Britain is drawing to a welcome close.Yet while lockdown eases, businesses re-open and millions bask on our sunny beaches, the skies are darkening in the distance.This gathering storm is not a potential second spike in infections - rather, it is an economic catastrophe.In the coming months, hard times could descend on Britain, fuelled by soaring unemployment and business failures.The Bank of England has already warned that we could be facing the worst slump for three centuries.In the current quarter, the economy could shrink by an incredible  per cent, as entire sectors like the hospitality trade and the travel business are devastated.“The unthinkable is now very much the reality,” says Stephen Phipson of the industrial body Make UK, whose latest survey found that  per cent of manufacturing firms are planning to lay off workers in the next six months.More than , bars and restaurants could remain permanently closed even when the lockdown is fully lted, while car sales in April were down  per cent compared to the same period last year.Under the energetic Rishi Sunak, the Government’s response has been to splash the cash in a determined - and understandable - attempt to keep the economy going.No less than £billion so far has been spent on the furlough job protection scheme, which pays  per cent of the wages of .million employees.Another £.billion has gone on a similar scheme for .million self-employed people.And a further £.billion has been swallowed up by business “bounce back” loans, half of which are unlikely to be repaid.Altogether coronavirus staff support could have cost the taxpayer over £billion by October, when furlough is due to end.But, far from phasing out state aid, the Government is likely to expand its scope over the coming months.The Treasury is now working on a plan called Project Birch, under which the Government will bail out a number of strategically important firms, either by providing large loans or by taking a stake in them.“Where a viable company has exhausted all options and its failure would disproportionately harm the economy, we may consider support on a last resort basis,” said a Treasury spokesman this week.Aerospace, manufacturing, steel production and car making are likely to be targeted.This policy would represent a huge change from the previous economic approach.Since Margaret Thatcher’s time, British governments have tried to avoid direct backing for companies, not least because such intervention is generally against European Union competition law.But the coronavirus has dramatically changed everything. Conventional wisdom about sound money and financial prudence has disappeared.Until recently the enemies of socialism, the Conservatives have now become converts to government action.Mrs Thatcher famously talked about “rolling back the frontiers of the state.”Now, in the wake of the Covid crisis, they have come sweeping forward once more.In the process, the public finances have taken a battering.In April the Government borrowed over £billion, a larger sum than for the whole of .The fiscal deficit is now projected to reach no less than £billion, perhaps even £billion in the worst case scenario.At the same time, more than million people — more than half the entire national workforce — are effectively on the state payroll.Even as lockdown eases, much of the economy has now been taken into the custody of the state.All this has to be paid for — and the bills cannot be met simply by printing more money.That is the route to a debased currency, soaring interest rates and hyperinflation.The reality is that massive state intervention is simply not sustainable except in an emergency.If printing money were the recipe for prosperity, then Zimbabwe would be the richest country on earth rather than mired in poverty.That is the lesson of history.If the Government carries on spending and intervening on a level that would have even made Jeremy Corbyn blush, then our country will be in real danger of sliding back to the dark days of the s.Gripped by industrial unrest and economic decline, Britain then was known as the “sick man of Europe”.Because of extravagant spending, the public finances were in a desperate state. In  inflation reached  per cent.The following year, Britain’s deficit was so enormous that the Government humiliatingly had to ask for a £.billion handout from the IMF.With the economy limping from one crisis to another, taxes soared, with the top rate on “unearned income” reaching  per cent.Some of the revenue was swallowed up in bailouts of troubled companies.In  the engine and car maker Rolls-Royce was rescued, followed by the Upper Clyde shipbuilders in  and volume motor manufacturer British Leyland in .Indeed, this was an era of institutionalised bullying by the strike-happy trade unions, who held the Government and the nation to ransom by flexing their industrial muscle.When Sir Horace Cutler, the Tory leader of the Greater London Council in the late s, was asked how many people work for London Transport, he replied, “about half of them.”In , which saw the Winter of Discontent, no fewer than million working days were lost to stoppages.At the peak of the disruption, bodies were left unburied and rubbish piled high in the street.The very fabric of society appeared to be falling part.“There is madness in the air,” recorded Bernard Donoghue, an aide to the Prime Minister Jim Callaghan.It was precisely the public’s revulsion at failed socialism and trade union irresponsibility that brought Margaret Thatcher to power in  on a  of reviving the economy.She achieved it by taming the unions, reinvigorating enterprise, restoring the work ethic and shrinking the Government.We need the same again today. All the good work of the last four decades will be undonewe slide back into the dependency culture, headed by a sprawling, sclerotic state machine.The only sure foundation on which to build a lasting recovery is by the wealth creation of the private sector.In practice that means the Government’s priority must be to encourage commerce and competition, not to dish out subsidies.So businesses should be urged to re-open as soon as possible, backed up by reductions in corporation tax and rates.Barriers to growth, like the strict social distancing limits, should be lted.At the same time, the Government should drop its plans to impose heavy-handed rules on quarantine for all travellers to Britain.It is a policy that will do nothing to protect public health but will cause huge damage to the economy, especially the travel industry.Similarly, Britain’s highly flexible labour market — the engine of the job creation miracle since  — must be maintained in the face of demands for more regulations.The best support that the Government can provide is not bailouts and bureaucracy, but a dynamic business environment along with a strong civic infrastructure, including modernised transport links and improved broadband.Soon after he became Prime Minister in , Jim Callaghan said: “We used to think we could spend our way out of recession. I tell you in all candour, that option no longer exists.”Under siege from inflation and the unions, his government was unable to abide by those sensible words.But as we come out of lockdown, their truth is more important than ever.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: girl arm blown off after gas explosion
story: The girls -year-old mum was also injured in the blast which took place in an allotment garden in Hamelin, Lower Saxony on Saturday.The girls father and another man were using the angle grinder to cut open a petrol barrel.Police said that the men failed to checkthere was any fuel remaining inside the barrel.Once they cut through the metal, sparks flew from the grinder which ignited the remaining petrol.The gases exploded, launching the barrels lid at the youngster and taking off her arm, NDR  Lower Saxony reported.Two air ambulances attended and took the girl and her mother to hospital where both are in a critical condition.The two men escaped with minor injuries. title: coronavirus laws four weeks longer wait lockdown
story: The Health Secretary confirmed the change in writing at the bottom of his ministerial statement - and said it would allow the government more time to make crucial decisions on what to lt next.Previously they were reviewed every  days, but now that will be extended to every  days.In his written statement to MPs today, the Health Secretary said that he needed more time to look at whether easing any lockdown measures would have had an impact on the rate of transmission.The extra week will give more time to study the effects of changing the rules, and to make sure the R doesnt go above one.He said: To ensure that we are making future decisions about the lockdown at the right time, the maximum review period will change from  days to  days.This will allow decisions to align more closely with the period of time necessary to assess the impact of previous changes on key data feeds, including the R rate.The Government will also keep all the measures under continual review and will account to Parliament on an ongoing basis.The change means that the next lockdown review is expected to be now on June , instead.And it will also mean that there are only three chances left for Brits to get the green light for a summer break - before the end of the school holidays.Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland can all still follow their own exit timetable, and the move could further increase the lockdown dferences within the UK.Last week Boris Johnson announced that he would lt some lockdown measures.People in England can now meet in groups of up to six - as long as they are outside.Schools opened their doors to more pupils yesterday, alongside outdoor markets and car showrooms.More kids are set toto the classrooms in the coming weeks, and non-essential retail shops are set to open again from June  too.From July more rules are set to be relaxed, including the possibility that restaurants and pubs will be allowed to reopen.Hairdressers, hotels and other outlets are also pinning their hopes on a late summer opening.But today the PMs spokesperson insisted that any lting of lockdown rules is still dependent on how the country is doing in its battle against the virus at the time.The Government has said its not afraid to put in place local lockdownsnew outbreaks flare up.And Boris Johnson could put in a UK-wide shutdown againcases rise across the country.However, Mr Hancock has insisted the UKs new test and trace system will be efficient in tracking down every new case of the bug.Anyone who tests positive will be asked to hand over the phone numbers of people they have been in recent contact with.They will then be asked to isolate themselves for  days to make sure they dont pass on the bug to any more people.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ibuprofen improve coronavirus survival rate 80 preventing serious cases
story: IBUPROFEN could be the key to treating severe cases of coronavirus, doctors hope.The cheap painkiller could help improve survival rates by up to  per cent, and reduce the need for patients to be treated in intensive care.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesIt comes after controversy early on during the pandemic, over fears the anti-inflammatory may make Covid- worse.French health minister Olivier Veran suggested the drug could worsen infections, and prompted Sir Patrick Vallance, Englands chief scientic adviser, to tell Brits to take paracetamol instead. The NHS also removed ibuprofen as a suggested treatment for mild cases. But, a subsequent study suggested the drug did not worsen or improve patients conditions.Now, a team of scientists in London are starting a new clinical trial to seethe anti-inflammatory could in fact help speed up the recovery in some patients by reducing serious side effects.Its hoped the drug could lead to shorter hospital stays and fewer people ending up in intensive care units .Animal studies have shown that the treatment can increase survival rates by  per cent.Prof Mitul Mehta, whos leading the trial at KCL, told PA: This is very promising, but of course it is an animal study, so we want to translate that really compelling result into humans.Its a trial for patients with Covid- disease to seegiving them an anti-inflammatory drug - a specic form of ibuprofen - will reduce the respiratory problems they have.Prof Mehta stressed that the trial was for patients already in hospital, not those with mild or suspected Covid-.Volunteers will be selected from patients who are in hospital, but that are not so ill they need intensive care.Prof Mehta said: If we can reduce their symptoms at that stage we have a number of benefits. We could reduce the amount of time someone spends in hospital - they might recover quicker and go home, thats obviously a fantastic outcome.We also might be reduce the degree of respiratory distress so that it can be managed in the hospital setting, without needing to go to ICU, and thats a fantastic outcome as well.Theoretically, this treatment, given at this time, should be beneficial.But, of course, this is based on animal studies. Its based on case reports, we need to do a trial to show that the evidence actually matches what we expect to happen.The Liberate trial is being carried out at KCL as well as Guys and St Thomass NHS Foundation Trust, along with the pharmaceutical organisation, the SEEK Group.Half of the patients taking part will be given standard care, while the other half will receive standard care as well as the special ibuprofen formulation.Prof Matthew Hotopf, director of the NIHR Maudsley Biomedical Research Centre, said: This highly innovative therapeutic approach seeks to rapidly advance a potentially important new treatment.If successful, the global public health value of this trial would be immense given the low cost and availability of this medicine.Earlier this year, at the start of the pandemic, there was some controversy over the use of ibuprofen after a French health minister advised against using it.Scientists in the UK launched a review and the NHS removed the drug as a recommended treatment for mild cases. But the findings showed ibuprofen does not make Covid infections better or worse.The Commission on Human Medicines expert working group concluded: There is currently insufficient evidence to establish a link between use of ibuprofen and susceptibility to contracting Covid- or the worsening of symptoms. To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: aldi shopper ban basket pint milk
story: Lee Nutbean popped into the Plymouth shop last week to get the item and says he was refused entry without a basket under company policy.The disgruntled shopper, , called customer services and was told to head back to the store and tell the manager it wasnt a policy he could enforce.But at the shop he was told having a basket is a local decision [the manager] has made for the store, and was subsequently banned.Mr Nutbean complained to the helpline again and was advised to speak with the manager to bring an end to the situation.He said: The manager then explained how having a basket is a local decision he has made for the store, as it makes things easier for them at the till, and this decision still stands.I told him I was getting confused as customer services are saying I dont need a basket. title: lidl shopper stunned swimsuit top
story: Lynn Ruane, who was dressed in a swimsuit and a sarong, was asked to wear a dferent top next time she visited the Dublin store.It came as temperatures soared to C across Britain and Ireland in what has been the hottest Spring ever recorded for the UK.Ms Ruane, who is an Independent Senator in Seanad Éireann, shared her frustration on Twitter, writing: @lidl_ireland wants me to wear a dferent top to shop there apparently.Asme wearing a swimsuit for a top in the summer is any dferent to any other little tank top Id wear.Get a grip. Men walking around in vests showing just as much skin.The Senator later admitted that maybe you could see too much of her bottom half.She added: I went home. Checked the mirror.Berated myself that maybe you could see too much of my upper thigh through my sarong .Lidl Ireland were quick to respond to the post, with Ruanne later adding: @lidl_ireland have communicated with me very promptly, apologised for the incident and Im glad they will be communicating their policy with the store and security involved.A spokesperson for Lidl Ireland revealed the worker was from a third party security company and not a Lidl employee.The spokesperson said in a statement: We have been made aware of a situation in a store regarding an inappropriate comment to a customer regarding her clothing.This comment was made by a member of Lidl’s third party security company and not by a Lidl employee.In an effort to manage social distancing there are increased levels of security in stores and many of these guards are not overly familiar with store policies.We have been in touch with the customer to apologise directly and we have contacted the company to ensure that all third party staff contracted to Lidl are re-briefed on policies.

title: china delayed coronavirus data saved thousands weeks who
story: CHINA delayed the release of coronavirus data that could have saved lives for two weeks, a leaked WHO report has claimed. The news comes after months of speculation about attempts by the countrys regime to cover up the extent of the outbreak in the beginning.The WHO publicly praised Chinas cooperation at the time, but the plaudits were reportedly only part of an attempt to abstract more information from the government.A report compiled by the World Health Organisation describes how three government labs succeeded in sequencing the viruss genome over a week before it was published on January , the Associated Press reported.Sequencing was an essential step towards understanding the behaviour of the virus and developing a vaccine, and was first accomplished by the Wuhan Institute of Virology on January .Interviews and internal documents reportedly suggested that the delay releasing the data was caused by tight controls on information as well as competition within the Chinese healthcare system.Even after the data had been released, China reportedly delayed for another two weeks as the WHO tried to obtain from them detailed data on patients and the number of coronavirus infections.Maria Van Kerkhove, a US epidemiologist who is now the WHOs technical lead in the fight against coronavirus, said in one meeting: Were going on very minimal information.Its clearly not enough for you to do proper planning.Speaking to the Associated Press, Ali Mokdad, a professor at the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington, said it was obvious that we could have saved more livesswter action had been taken.The WHO publicly praised Chinas cooperation at the time, but the plaudits were reportedly only part of an attempt to abstract more information from the government.In another meeting, Dr Gauden Galea, the WHOs most senior official in China, said: Were currently at the stage where yes, theyre giving it to us  minutes before it appears on [state media].In a speech at the Wealth Health Assembly last month, Chinese President Xi Jinping claimed China had always provided information to the WHO in a most timely fashion.He also pledged billion over the next two years to help fight the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.Todays report comes after officials in Wuhan, where the outbreak began late last year, said that no new cases of the virus had been found after a round of testing that reached .million of the citys million people.It also follows earlier reports that China threatened the WHO into delaying warnings about Covid- while it stockpiled medical supplies.

title: meghan markle complains kate snaps fingers palace running
story: The actress has told pals she had little support when she was shredded by the media - whereas Kate has the backing of the royals when she faces negative reports, according to the DailyMailIt comes after society bible Tatler ran a cover story about Kate - title: government wins vote against vote from home
story: Furious MPs took selfies as they waited in the queue for  minutes, branding the system a farce.Speaker Sir Lindsay Hoyle and his officials were left repeatedly shouting instructions at MPs as social distancing measures required them to join a queue, keep two metres apart, walk through the Commons chamber and announce their vote.The queue stretched for several hundred metres, snaking through Westminster Hall and running to Portcullis House, the newer part of the parliamentary estate.They were compared to the huge queues for IKEA that were seen this week. Some shoppers were forced to wait for three hours to get into the store.It came as the Government dropped procedures which allowed MPs to vote online and speak remotely via Zoom, thereby requiring them to appear in person to take part.Conservative Karen Bradley, who chairs the Procedure Committee, moved an amendment to keep remote voting in place in the coming weeks, with several Conservative MPs rebelling to support the proposal.But it was defeated by  votes to , majority , following a -minute ision.MPs later approved the Governments motion to only allow them to vote in person by  votes to , majority .After Ms Bradleys amendment to the Governments motion was pushed to a vote, Sir Lindsay said the queuing system would continue as it is the only method that is compatible with Government-set requirements and those from Public Health England.As some MPs dallied, Sir Lindsay could be heard telling them: Why are we not keeping up  There are other members waiting.Some MPs also appeared confused at the new voting procedures.Some Conservative MPs attempted to exit the chamber via the wrong door, despite being told by the Speaker moments earlier which way to go.DUP MP Jim Shannon initially walked up to the noes column, before correcting himself and walking through the ayes section.During the debate, Sir Lindsay appealed for a bit of give and take from the Government and opposition parties to ensure all MPs can continue to vote.Commons Leader Jacob Rees-Mogg said he would table a motion on Wednesday which would enable MPs unable to attend Parliament on medical grounds to take part in certain proceedings, including questions, urgent questions and ministerial statements.Mr Rees-Mogg said: The stopgap of a hybrid Parliament was a necessary compromise during the peak of the virus, but by not being here the House has not worked effectively on behalf of constituents.He added he expects teething problems with the new voting system which involves queuing, adding it will be some time before our proceedings are fully restored.Labours Chris Bryant joked have you ever been to Alton Towers to which Mr Rees-Mogg replied: Indeed, yes I have, I took my sister Annunziata there many years ago.Enough of my reminisces because it is important that we protect, preserve, prioritise our parliamentary democracy, it has to continue regardless of the disease that is afflicting the nation.For Labour, shadow Commons leader Valerie Vaz questionedMr Rees-Mogg was living in another universe as the Covid- pandemic is ongoing before she asked questions on whether a risk assessment had been conducted for Black, Asian, and minority ethnicparliamentary staff required back on the estate.Ms Bradley said the current arrangements for a physical parliament are far from optimal, adding she was a traditionalist who wanted ato normal as soon as possible.But she also highlighted a conversation she had with Conservative MP Robert Halfon who was advised by his doctor that he must not attend Parliament for health reasons.She said: The idea that we decide today to disenfranchise him completely seems to me to be absurd.Tory former minister Jeremy Wright said it cannot be right to exclude from our decision making any member against their will unless it is done for reasons of principle or because it is unavoidable.Caroline Nokes, Tory chairwoman of the Women and Equalities Committee, branded the proposed measures discriminatory.She said: These measures do not just look discriminatory, they are discriminatory.Instantly a number of groups with protected characteristics are excluded, those who are pregnant or new mothers.Older members might be advised not to come here via public transport.The underlying health conditions of either members or their families are, to be frank none of our business, but they will be excluded.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: two metre social distancing economy
story: IN parks and on pavements up and down the land you cannot escape the numerous signs telling us to stand at least two metres apart.It has become the new normal — stand back, give people space, don’t spread the virus. And Britain has been very good at it.But as we slowly move out of lockdown with thoughts of shopping, seeing our friends and family, and a cool drink in a pub garden, how effective this two-metre rule actually is has become a new national obsession.Many are starting to ask: Do we really need to keep a two-metre gap  Could it in fact be ONE metre  It may sound trivial, a metre is still too far to hug, kiss, even to shake hands with friends and loved ones.But for many businesses which rely on allowing people to gather more closely — theatres, restaurants, pubs, to name but a few — cutting the official social distance in half could be the dference between keeping afloat or going under.The official advice of the World Health Organization is that one metre is sufficient, a belief shared by the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control.The Danes changed their position three weeks ago to one metre and most of the European countries’ public health officials advise one metre in certain circumstances.Now a new study by the WHO has found that while a two-metre distance reduced the risk of the virus being passed on to . per cent, a one-metre gap only increased the chance of transmission to . per cent.So a small risk either way, but enough to justy potentially endangering some of the industries we both enjoy and, for many thousands, rely upon for work. I have been asking for a couple of months how that distance was established, yet its origins are very obscure.It seems to go back to research on the distance between beds in the old-fashioned Nightingale wards in the s. It has become a folklore of infection control and public health, until people have started asking questions about it today.Experiments about the distance droplets travel have been conducted under such articial conditions that they are not applicable to everyday lives.Laboratory air is articially still, whereas air is not still, even when you are sitting in a room with all the windows and doors closed. Air flow breaks up the particles from a sneeze or a cough and they tend to fall pretty quickly on to your clothes or face.The serious risk of infection is when you get up to half a metre away from somebody with Covid- who sneezes or coughs.But the dference between one metre and two metres is the dference between a very small risk and a very tiny risk.To the economy, the dference is a radical one. Shting from two metres to one metre would allow us to get back to something close to business as usual. If you imagine a two-metre circle drawn around any inidual, that takes up  and a half square metres.When you come down to a one-metre safe zone, it is only . square metres. So you could get four times as many people into any given space. With the two-metre rule,  per cent of pubs and bars say it wouldn’t be economically viable to reopen. With four times as many customers, only small pubs would face dficulties.The current approach doesn’t grasp that town centres are leisure destinations and that people won’t go outit is an unpleasant experience. Shoppers want to have a coffee, lunch, try on clothes, it is a social activity with their friends.I believe that cinemas are safe to reopen and that perhaps we might be able to allow some fans back into football stadiums to cheer on their teams again.In a typical cinema, where seating is tiered and there is air conditioning,you do happen to be coughing out, the thermal heat from the bodies should rise it up out into the air conditioning system.Allowing fans to attend football matches again would be a challenge, because of the congestion going into the stadium.They would have to carefully plan entrance and exit times and leave every other seat vacant unless there is a family group, so you would probably be playing in front of a stadium which is  per cent full.I may be part of a faction that favours one metre, but the consensus is that the risk of transmission outside is very low.So joggers don’t have to go into the road to avoid getting too close to someone  on the pavement — because their slipstream will mean the droplets will probably stick to them anyway.The best way to reduce the risk of the virus spreading is a good standard of hygiene, sanitising your hands at the end of a journey and after eating.If you are involved in a lot of customer interactions, such as supermarket checkouts, Perspex barriers are helpful.The Government has taken so much flak on easing lockdown restrictions that they seem to be reluctant to get into a fight on this one. But we need to remember that interrupting the transmission of the virus is not about rules and their enforcement.It is about assessing the risk at each inidual venue, because sticking to two metres in all cases poses a risk to our economic health.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: nightclub coronavirus ibiza coronavirus wayne lineker

but nightclubs around the world are looking for new ways to reopen.Wayne is confident that Linekers can reopen on July  to welcome the seasons first guests.Meanwhile, Spains National Federation of Leisure and Entertainment Businesses have drawn up a new raft of measures for venues to crackdown on coronavirus.Plans recommend all clubbers will have to wear facemasks and will have to wash their hands as they enter and leave.Customers will also not be able to mix drinks, and they will only be served with disposable straws.Seating areas will also be reserved, while markings on the floor will help people keep their social distance.Drinks will have to be ordered on an app to avoid clusters of people at busy bars.And while Wayne has closed off his dancefloor, the new guidelines say you can have one - title: keeping pubs afloat sun says
story: WE would put up with a lot to get back to the pub. We’re just not sure we’ll ­recognise the experience under the ­Government’s plans for them.Perspex screens protecting staff who will barely interact with punters ­anyway. Drinks ordered by app, then wordlessly collected from the bar.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesStrict limits on numbers, with the dubious two-metre distancing rigidly observed. Costly new ventilation systems supposedly dispersing the virus.Hardly a cosy and inviting prospect. Butit keeps our pubs afloat, great. We dearly hope it will last only a few weeks.The signs are looking up. Oxford Professor Carl Heneghan reckons our death rate will be at “normal” levels next week, with zero Covid deaths by July.Another eminent professor says there is no ­evidence a second wave will hit us.Even a holiday looks a little more likely. EasyJet will fly to  per cent of its destinations by August.Yet half of Britain remains hooked on the lockdown, unwilling to venture out, to narrow the two-metre rule . . . terried of even the gentlest easing of rules.And many are better off than before. In April we paid off a record £.billion of personal debt and tripled our monthly savings to £.billion. That’s thanks to generous furlough payments, mortgage holidays and saved daily expenses.Far too many think this surreal situation is sustainable. It is not. A huge crash is coming when the bailouts end.The faster weto normality, the less horric its impact will be. WHEN is quarantine not quarantine  When you can still go out — even on the bus.This contradictory fudge is, incredibly, what the Government has come up with, caught between those wanting to lock visitors up for a fortnight and those, like The Sun, who believe that would wreck tourism, our economy and vast numbers of jobs.Quarantining already looks bonkers at this stage. This half-measure is a joke:Restrictive enough to deter most travellers, but not enough to prevent badly infected arrivals from passing Covid on. And farcical enough to further erode trust in the Government.IT should not take George Floyd’s appalling murder and the ensuing protests to remind the world that black lives matter.That sentiment was also why it was vital for Public Health England to find out exactly why BAME people have a higher risk of dying from Covid — and to recommend counter-measures.Why didn’t it  The PHE report just restates what we knew. It failed even to allow for obesity or a victim’s job — both crucial factors. Now a Government minister is having to probe it all further.Another PHE shambles.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: family boy devastated blown inflatable wind
story: Little Ben Duffy was on a dinghy while his family played nearby, but a gust of wind pushed the boat out into deeper water, their local priest has said.By the time the inflatable was caught up with, the boy was missing and a frantic search was sparked.Tragically, it was called off in the early hours of Tuesday morning after his body was found by rescuers.Partry parish priest Fr John Kenny told The Irish Sun: “It’s a safe bathing area on the lake but the little boy was on a little dinghy and the wind took the craft out further than where it would have been safe for him to be.“And it drted onto the lake further than anybody would go bathing.“When they caught up with the dinghy he wasn’t in it anymore so we don’t know what happened - expect he must have fallen out or jumped out.”Do you know the family involved in the tragedy  Get in touch on tips@the-sun or Fr Kenny added: “The family were using the little dinghy as part of the fun and games in the shallow safe part of the lake but he went a bit too far with it and the wind brought it further.“Wherever it went to, it appearshe would have stayed on it, he might have been safer but he must have fallen out for some reason.“It’s a tight-knit community and the boy went to the local school and some of his classmates and neighbours would have been swimming in the local vicinity swimming in the same area where it happened.“I know the family well. They’re very active in the parish through the school mostly but they’re also very parish involved and anything to do with local sports or organisations.“Ben was a lovely little boy. He was one of the youngest in his class. He was bright-eyed, literally bright-eyed and cheerful.Always full of le but particularly he was a very smiley little boy.“The whole community feels for the loss of Ben for his family and we convey our sympathies and we want them to all know we’re here for them even though it’s dficult particularly with all the restrictions. It makes it even more poignant.”The tragic accident happened near the Tourmakeady side of the Lough Mask in Co Mayo at around :pm on Monday.The Irish Sun understands Ben, who was a Junior Infants student at Scoil NaisiuntaThuar Mhic Eadaigh, was one of five children to parents Alan and Tracey - it is believed he had three brothers and one sister.Fr Kenny added: “The family are obviously devastated and the community are in shock. What was a normal summer’s day turned into a tragedy in a matter of minutes.“I happened to be in the vicinity when it happened running an outdoor charity raffle and when we saw the helicopters coming we called everything off and some of us made our way to the shoreline to be with the family.“Local people had begun the search already. Everyone on the shoreline felt so helpless and sad for the family.”The family who have been described as “popular” were heavily involved in the community in GAA and football and mum Tracey is believed to teach dance.Obviously, what was a very enjoyable day no doubt for families turned into disaster with the loss of a young five-year-old boy.“With Covid, everything was tied down with no school, no nothing over the last few months and the Bank Holiday weekend comes and there was a little bit of freedom.“I suppose people felt like they could go down to the lake because they live very close to it. To think it turned into such a disaster is unbelievable.The Fine Gael councillor also praised all the people who were involved in the search effort for Ben.A Garda spokesman said: “Gardai in Castlebar assisted by Coast Guard, Civil Defence, Lough Mask Water Rescue and local ers can confirm that the search operation for the five-year-old boy has been stood down as his body was recovered from Lough Mask.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rubbish urine bbq booze litter britain beaches
story: SHOCKING pictures show piles of rubbish, bottles of urine and used BBQs left on Britains beaches during the sunshine.People making daytrips after spending weeks at home have been slammed for not cleaning up after themselves and leaving the beauty spots in a much worse state compared to just weeks ago.Thousands of Brits have flocked to the coast during weeks of sunny weather and lockdown relaxations, and have left plenty of litter.Just a few weeks ago these spots were mostly people and litter-free as the country remained in stricter lockdown, but relaxing of the rules have seen people swarm beaches.Families and friends were pictures sitting close together at ious UK beauty spots this weekend - making it impossible to keep social distances and keep the areas clean and tidy in many cases.A foul outcome of these daytrips has been bottles of urine left behind, as public toilets are closed as the coronavirus pandemic continues.The phenomenon, known as “fly peeing”, is causing beauty spots to turn into public toilets, and the bottles to pile up along roads and beaches.Small coastal villages with limited facilities, such as Weybourne in Norfolk, have been covered in bottles of urine and nappies.Lyndon Swt, the parish council chairman, said: “The car park is inundated and we have zero toilet facilities so the beaches and hedgerows are filling with toilet paper.”Becky Jarrett hit out on social media, saying: “They had to open a load of loos on the Norfolk coast for the bank holiday weekend due to people leaving bottles of wee and heaps of poo and dirty nappies all over the beaches here the week before.“Disgusting idiots.”On the other side of the country a care worker from Burnham-on-sea, Somerset, reported people urinating in public against her garden fence.Others said boozy Brits caught short had even defecated in private gardens.Crowds on beaches and clfs at Durdle Door over the weekend showed a shocking disregard for the area, a conservation charity said.Lucy Culkin, chief executive of the The Jurassic Coast Trust, said it had received hundreds of messages from members of the public since the weekend.She said these highlighted the appalling volume of litter on beaches, including human waste, sanitary items, and surgical masks and gloves, as well as disposable barbecues.The lack of respect for our coastline shown by some has deeply saddened our local communities and visitors alike, she said.It was clear to see that some had all but forgotten the guidelines of social distancing or welfare for themselves and others, or indeed any respect for the natural environment they were visiting.And calls have been made to ban people from Skegness beach after pictures of litter strewn across the popular attraction were posted online.Papers, beer cans and disposable barbecues were among the items left behind by visitors across several parts of the resort.The images were shared online by the RNLI East of England, which appealed with people to take their rubbish home.The organisation wrote on Facebook: If youre making the most of this weather at the beach... please take your litter with you!There are plenty of bins to choose from.The revelations sparked outrage, with many calling on the Government to reintroduce the ban on people visiting beaches.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. But now there’s light at the end of the tunnel, as some children begin toto school from this week. Schools have remained open to support vulnerable children and key workers’ kids, but now nursery and reception plus years  and  are getting ready to go back too. Secondary schools will also offer some face-to-face support to pupils in years  and  as they prepare for their exams next year. As any parent knows, telling younger children to stay two metres apart will be a challenge, so it’s recommended that they only mix in the same small groups each day.  Andrea Parker is lead head teacher of three London primary schools, Bonneville, Jessop and Stockwell. She explains how a “bubbles” system will work: “There will be a maximum of  children in class. In our reception classes, we’ve got around eight children in each bubble. And it’s not just about the size of the bubble, it’s about the dynamics of the bubble as well. Children are people. “We’re going to really use more of our outdoor space for reception in particular, where they will be working in smaller groups. We’ll be removing all soft furnishings, and with things like the climbing frames only one bubble can use it at any one time and then it will be cleaned down before another bubble can use it.”  Staggering the drop-off and pick-up times is important to keep children and their carers safe – and schools are putting a new system into place. “We’ve got lines painted at the entrance a two-metre distance from the boundary of the school for drop-off,” says Ms Parker. “The bubble lead will be there for  minutes, and will then take her group through a marked route to their room. And then there’ll be  minutes after that for parents to leave the streets and to wait for any late children that might come here afterwards.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA Health Minister has said he canapost promise pent-up Brits will be able to take a foreign holiday - even by the end of this year. Edward Argar refused to guarantee youaposll have a summer getaway - despite the government hoping to install air bridges as soon as this month. An air bridge is an agreement between the UK and one other country, which will let people travel freely between the two nations without going into quarantine when they arrive. It would spare tourists and ing Brits from having to isolate for  days when they enter the UK - a policy that takes force on Monday. Portugalaposs foreign minister today confirmed air bridge talks are under way and said people from the UK would be most welcome this summer. But for an air bridge to work, both countries will need to have a similar low infection rate to reduce the risk of a new Covid- outbreak. And Britain has one of the worst death rates in the world, with thousands of new infections still spreading per day - and the alert level still at . Another  deaths of people with Covid- were confirmed yesterday - as the overall official death toll in the UK topped ,. Despite hopes of an air bridge system, Boris Johnson reportedly told his Cabinet yesterday that Brits may have to take holidays at home rather than abroad.  Mr Argar said he hoped people would be able to go on holiday this year.But quizzed repeatedly by the BBC he was unable to name a single country that had a worse infection rate than Britain. And he told BBC Breakfast: “I’m not going to say a particular date on when that might happen.  Because we will have to be guided by how the disease behaves, controlling any risk of a second wave and controlling the disease. “I hope that people will be able to go on holiday at some point this year. But I can’t make that promise because I have to be cautious and go with the science. “And I don’t have that forward view yet of how a second wave or otherwise might behave.” It comes despite Health Secretary Matt Hancock saying the Government was considering relaxing border quarantine rules - before they had even come into force. Home Secretary Priti Patel will present full rules on the -day quarantine plan to parliament today, with spot checks and £, fines for those who refuse to isolate. There will be exceptions for jobs like lorry drivers and scientists - while people will be able to leave their homes for food, medicine or funerals. But anxious ministers want to gradually replace the system with air bridges as soon as the end of June, after travel bosses warned the plan will be a “disaster”. So-called bridges could be built to  countries where the virus is under control, including Spain, Portugal and Greece.   No confirmed the quarantine rules will be reviewed after three weeks, which could lead to exemptions for some popular holiday destinations. And it would be in time for school holidays. At last night’s No briefing, Mr Hancock said he was growing “more optimistic” about the prospect of Brits taking holidays abroad this year. But he said: “Clearly the number one priority is keeping the public safe. “That is the overriding principle and it has been throughout this.”

title: summer holidays back cards relaxation
story: NewsSummer holidays back on the cards as relaxation of quarantine rules consideredTravel bosses have warned against forcing UK arrivals into quarantine for two weeks and instead pushed for air bridges with  countries where coronavirus is under control, including Spain, Portugal and GreeceShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsSummer holidays are back on the cards as the Government considers relaxing quarantine rules " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailSizzling temperatures and packed beaches put people in the holiday mood today – just as their chances of a summer getaway started to look up. Health Secretary Matt Hancock said the Government was considering relaxing border quarantine rules before they had even come into force. As travel bosses warned forcing UK arrivals into quarantine for two weeks would be a “disaster”, airlines pressed for “air bridges” with  countries where the virus is under control, including Spain, Portugal and Greece. Travellers ing from those nations would not have to isolate. PM Boris Johnson is pressing ahead with border quarantine plans as of Monday, despite a growing backlash. But No confirmed the rules will be reviewed after three weeks, which could lead to exemptions for some popular holiday destinations. And it would be in time for school holidays. At tonight’s No briefing, Mr Hancock said he was growing “more optimistic” about the prospect of Brits taking holidays abroad this year. But he said: “Clearly the number one priority is keeping the public safe. “That is the overriding principle and it has been throughout this.” Later Transport Secretary Grant Shapps said: “These measures will be reviewed every few weeks, and we are working to see how we can introduce agreements with other countries when safe to do so, so we can go abroad and tourists can come here.” George Morgan-Grenville, CEO of tour firm Red Savannah, accused the Government of “ignoring the devastation” the quarantine plan would cause.  He said: “By pursuing its quarantine plans without due regard for the economic consequences, the Government is choosing to ignore the devastation it will cause to companies, to employment and to the lives of all those whose jobs will be lost. “The quarantine measures are a blunt weapon which will bring only economic disaster.” EasyJet today revealed it plans to resume flights on as many as half of its routes by the end of July, and almost a quarter of Majorca’s , hotels expect to reopen next month, something local tourism chiefs said was an “unthinkable turnaround” from a month ago.  At the end of June, , German tourists will be invited to the island to test new safety protocols. And many Brits are still planning a  getaway, a poll suggests. More than half said they still intended to go on holiday later this year, despite Foreign Office guidelines advising against all-but-essential travel overseas. More than % of the , people quizzed by travel insurance provider Just Travel Cover had not been put off travelling abroad by the pandemic, despite more than half having holiday plans cancelled. Andrew Jackson, MD of the insurance broker, said: “This survey gives us reason to be optimistic.”  Home Secretary Priti Patel is expected to unveil full details of the quarantine plan in Parliament today . Early reports suggest people heading for quarantine will be allowed to take public transport and go outside for food shopping. The PM’s spokesman said: “I think there will be a limited set of exemptions, just as there was during the nationwide lockdown...they need urgent medical treatment, support from social services, food or medicine which they cannot get delivered, or to attend a funeral of a close relative.” He said air bridges were “something the Government is looking at”. Policy was focused on stopping “imported cases of this virus” and, he said, “one of the most devastating things which could happen to the economy is to have a second spike”.  The Home Office said people arriving in Britain would be contacted at random to ensure they are following orders – with rulebreakers facing a £, fine. Testing chief Professor John Newton said rules could be easedthe Test and Trace system was successful. He said: “If travellers are able to be tested and self-isolate in response to contact tracing just like a domestic new case, that would be another way of dealing with it. “At the moment caution has won the day.”

story: NewsBoy marks first birthday as donor law comes into force after his own transplantEXCLUSIVE Tommy Collins has become a symbol of hope for Max and Keiras Law through his liver transplant, which was initially pushed back because staff at Kings College Hospital in London were so busy battling coronavirusShareCommentsByJeremy Armstrong:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsTommy Collins is a symbol of hope for Max and Keiras Law" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA baby celebrated his first birthday on the day Max and Keira’s Law came into force – after a le-saving organ transplant from his dad. Now Tommy Collins is a symbol of hope for the Mirror-backed scheme, in which everyone in England is a potential donor after they die unless they opt out. Among the first to praise the new legislation were Tommy’s parents Alfie Collins and Maisie Davies. Dad Alfie,  – who donated a slice of liver for his son’s op – said: “We’d waited so long for a donor and in the end it felt right that I underwent the transplant for my boy. Actually I was a perfect match. The liver will grow in Tommy like a normal one and my own will regenerate inside me. It’s the body’s only organ that can do so.” He said the transplant has “transformed” le for Tommy, whose rare liver disease made him produce too much ammonia. That affected his brain, leaving him subject to fits.The transplant was conducted at King’s College Hospital in London on April  after being postponed because staff there were so busy battling the coronavirus crisis. There was a late drama when another donor was found as Alfie lay unconscious ready for the operation but surgeons opted to proceed after two earlier ones had proved to be unsuitable.Mum Maisie, , said she will never forget seeing “my two boys” head off for the operating theatre. “I prayed they would be safe,” added Maisie, who gave birth to Tommy at St Thomas’ Hospital where she is a receptionist. “This has given Tommy a new lease of le.”

title: brits urged take knee today
story: NewsBrits urged to take a knee today in solidarity with US George Floyd protestersStand Up to Racism has organised a protest in the UK at pm on Wednesday, June , amid widespread outrage at the killing of unarmed black man George Floyd while in police custodyShareCommentsByTess de la Mare:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsPeople in Hemel Hempstead hold up signs as they kneel during a protest against the death of George Floyd " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAn anti-racism campaign group is urging Brits to take the knee on their doorsteps for a socially distanced protest in solidarity with protesters in the US. Stand Up to Racismhas organised the protest for pm on Wednesday as part of a day of action against discrimination in response to the death of George Floyd in police custody in Minneapolis. The -year-old African American died last week after a police officer held him down by pressing a knee into his neck, provoking riots in many US cities and demonstrations across the world. SUTR said the campaign was inspired by the kneeling protest staged by American football star Colin Kaepernick in  that has become synonymous with the Black Lives Matter movement. A separate protest has been planned in Londonaposs Hyde Park at pm on Wednesday, while a further demonstration is scheduled for pm on Saturday in Parliament Square. On Tuesday, hundreds of people gathered outside St Georgeaposs Hall in Liverpool as part of a separate Black Lives Matter protest. Merseyside Police said in a tweet that while it recognised peopleaposs right to demonstrate peacefully they should still adhere to social distancing guidelines. It comes as a review by Public Health England found black, Asian and minority ethnicpeople are at signicantly higher risk of dying from Covid-.  Campaigners are now calling for a public inquiry into the disproportionate impact of Covid- on BAME communities. Weyman Bennett of SUTR said: Racism is the underlying condition that continues to kill black and BAME communities. Take the knee at pm because there is a boot on the neck of millions of people in the BAME community. Part of the cure for the virus of racism is to embrace anti-racism and anti-fascism. SUTRaposs Sabby Dhalu said: BAME communities are suffering disproportionately from Covid-, economic decline and police brutality. We call on people to apostake the kneeapos on their doorstep in solidarity with George Floyd, at pm, Wednesday  June. We stand for justice for George Floyd and say Black Lives Matter. Large gatherings are still banned under shutdown rules, and on Tuesday Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon asked protesters to find an alternative to physical demonstrations.  Speaking at her daily briefing in Edinburgh, she said: Right now, it is the case, unfortunately and regrettably, that large gatherings of people could pose a risk to health and indeed to le. We need to find ways of allowing people to make their voices heard and to make the points that many of us want to be made and to be heard right now, but to do so in a way that is safe and is not putting people protesting or wider communities at risk. The Met Police said its approach was to engage with protesters and encourage them to follow social distancing rules.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThis choir really is singing from the same sheet as every member has been touched by organ donation in some way and wants to help raise awareness of the vital issue. Musician and artist James Tottle set up Gted Organs two years ago to “spread the word and save more lives”. The -year-old, from Bath, Somerset, said: “Every day since I got my new heart in , I wanted to celebrate the second chance I’d been given.” So with help from friend and award-winning songwriter Julian Kay, he got together a dozen other organ recipients and in  they recorded their first song, Tomorrow. Word spread and by last September there were  members –  of whom came to Rockfield Studios, Monmouth, South Wales, to record new tracks Love of Mine and Heart and Soul. Choirmaster Julian, , said: “The opt-out system is coming in. But it’s still vital to have that conversation with loved ones before anything happens.” Visit the groupaposs Facebook page  Dylan Williams, , from Carmarthen In , Dylan had a pancreas and kidney transplant after battling Type  diabetes. He gives talks to schools and community groups on donation, saying “every day feels like I’ve won the lottery thanks to the kindness of strangers”. He said: “I’ve always loved singing, so I jumped at the chance to join Gted Organs. There can’t be a better motivation than to celebrate being alive!”  Stephen Heavyside, , from Barrow-in-Furness, Cumbria In , Stephen was put on the transplant list with kidney failure. We Tricia, also in the choir, stepped up and despite not being a blood match, a revolutionary “blood-wash” treatment meant he got her organ in April .  He said: “Tricia and I joined in , shortly after our transplant. We hadn’t been in a choir before but thoughtever there was a reason to sing, it was this. I know how lucky I am for Tricia to have saved my le but also how many aren’t so lucky. Hopefully our singing can give them some hope.”  Mark Smith, , of Harrogate, North Yorks Mark spent over  years trying to control his Type  diabetes but by his mid-s it was starting taking its toll. Put on the transplant list, in July  he had a kidney and pancreas swap. Since then, he and his we have managed to have two children and he gives talks to promote donation. He said: “It’s a brilliant thing, bringing together people from dferent parts of the country, all with our own stories but one theme – transplants save lives. I hope the songs reach out to lots of people and encourage them to have the conversation with friends and family.”  John Mould, , of Loughborough, Leicestershire In , John, the partner of choir member Jane Lynch, was diagnosed with blood cancer myelofibrosis. He needed a bone marrow transplant and sister Ruth was a match. The op happened in .  He said: “I feel blessed with this second chance. “There’s a real energy to the choir and that weekend recording those tracks was unforgettable.”  Lee Gibson, , from Barrow-in-Furness, Cumbria Lee joined with we Rachel in . She might not be here without her dad stepping up. He said: “I know how lucky we are to have had Rachel’s dad as a match. “My le would be so dferentthat hadn’t happened and getting with the choir and singing seems like the best way to express how grateful I am.”  Julian Kay, , from Chippenham, Wiltshire He said: “Since being involved with the Gted Organs I’ve come to know so many transplant patients and hear their stories.  As a result, I’ve made my family aware of my wish for my organs to be donated and hope these tracks will inspire thousands to follow suit.”  Mark Allen, , from Widnes, Cheshire Mark had a double lung transplant  years ago and is now waiting for a new kidney. He joined the original Gted Organs, a band project, in  as a keyboard player after meeting James Tottle at the Transplant Games. He said: “Being in the original band and now the choir has been a privilege to spread the word on organ donation. “The fact that we’re creating great songs shows what can be doneeveryone loves what they’re doing.”  Jane Lynch, , of Loughborough, Leicestershire Jane and John have been together  years and were in local choirs before joining Gted Organs last September. She said: “I thought I might lose John when he was diagnosed. Every day since then feels like a blessing. I jump at any chance to sing but the choir is special because everyone there is a survivor.”  Helen Presdee-Jones , from Cardf Helen was hit by renal failure aged , having a kidney transplant in  and then again in October last year when the first kidney failed.She said: “I’m so thankful to my donors and theirfamilies.Singing in this choir is a way I can celebrate my second – and third – chance at le.”  Tricia Heavyside, , from Barrow-in-Furness, Cumbria Two years ago, Tricia saved hubby Stephen by donating a kidney. She said she had to step up after watching his health deteriorate so rapidly. She said: “I saved Stephen’s le in what was our ruby wedding year. We’re so grateful to those amazing doctors when we really did think it was game over. Singing with Stephen after  years of marriage is bliss!”  Rachel Gibson, , from Barrow-in-Furness, Cumbria In , Rachel got a kidney from her dad after years of renal issues. The next year she wed and he walked her down the aisle.  She marked her op’s seventh anniversary by singing with Gted Organs. She said: “I heard about the choir from Steve and Tricia and love it more than I can describe. We share our transplant stories and celebrate le together in a way nobody  could really understand.”  Lewis Macmillan, , of Brydekirk, Dumfries and Galloway Lewis was born with a rare kidney condition and took  tablets a day. At , he got a kidney from his mum after a revolutionary procedure to change his blood type. Six years later this failed and he changed blood type again to get a kidney from his father. He said: “I met Kirsty last August at a kidney awareness weekend, who told me about the choir. The next weekend I did the -hour round-trip to Swansea to take part and loved it. “I always loved singing and can’t think of a better way to raise awareness of the human impact of donation.”  James Tottle, , of Bath, Somerset James had a heart transplant  years ago after suffering cardiomyopathy. He said: “I don’t know anything about my donor, so this is a big thank you to him or her. The Gted Organs motto is ‘Celebrate the gt of le through music’. Raising awareness is something I’m passionate about.”  Kirsty Avril Biss, , from Brighton Kirsty has known her whole le she would one day need a kidney op. On dialysis for three years, she finally got her organ in February last year.
