title: tv-celebrity-sends-message-earlston-high-school-pupils
story: EARLSTON High School pupils have been sent encouraging words from a TV celebrity.The X Factorjudge Louis Walsh posted a video message on Twitter today .The Irishman told pupils they should pluck up the courage to enter their school talent show, Earlstons Got Virtual Talent.He said: "Times running out ndash this is a big, big talent show: its called Earlstons Got Virtual Talent."I think youve got virtually a little bit of talent, so amuse us."Youve nothing to lose ndash send in a video."Sing, dance, be funny, play tricks ndash do anything ndash just do something, because youve got the time now to do it."So, come on, just show us what youve got."The pupils had previously been sent a video message from actor Jack Lowden, a former Earlston student.

title: aldi-launch-cooling-mats-stop-cats-dogs-overheating
story: Aldi has launched a new product for pets to stop them overheating and keep them cool during the summer months.The month of May has served as a pleasant reminder to the nation of how glorious the weather can sometimes be in the UK.Last week saw the hottest temperatures of the year so far and many people took to sunbathing in their gardens.To help keep your pet by your side, and feeling cool while you soak up the sun, the discount retailer is selling cooling mats priced from pound..They arepart of a iety of new pet accessories being launched in stores and online as part of the Specialbuys range.When did the pet mats go on sale The supermarket began selling the mats -along with other items in the pets Specialbuys range - on Thursday, May .Proving extremely popular, all of the rangersquos cooling mats have now sold out online at aldi and it is not known when they will be back in stock.However, you can still purchase the mats in store.What mat designs are there The range features ious designs, including a circular watermelon printed mat and a lemon version.The mats can be easily cleaned with wipes and stay dont require any freezing to keep them cool, as they are specically designed to remain at a cool temperature.What  is in the range As part of the pet range, Aldi is also selling a set of three cooling dog toys for pound. which includes a ball, shark and bone.Other items in the range include cooling pet bowls priced at pound. each and a luxury pet bed bundle for pound..Itrsquos worth noting thatyou choose to purchase any items in the range online, you will have to pay a delivery fee of pound.your order is under pound.

title: annoyed-borders-mum-accuses-teenagers-ignoring-lockdown
story: A BORDERS mum says groups of young people broke the updated lockdown rules at the weekend.The -year-old woman, who does not wish to be named, says she spotted several large groups failing to obey social distancing in Peebles on Friday evening .She said: ldquoItrsquos frustrating because no-one wants a second wave of this [coronavirus].Since Friday, Scots have been allowed to meet one other household outdoors as long as the total group contains no more than eight people and everyone remains two metres away from each other.However, the mum-of-two says she was ldquoannoyed by what she saw during a walk on Friday at around pm.She says she witnessed ldquofour or five groups of youths flouting the national guidelines as they gathered on the banks of the River Tweed.She said: ldquoThey were all the way along the river and there was no social distancing at all.ldquoThey were obviously there for a bit of a party ndash and there was rubbish everywhere.Most of the people were probably in their late teens, said the woman, adding: ldquoI get that itrsquos really, really hard for them not to see their friends.ldquoBut therersquos a little bit of, lsquoWhere do their parents think they arersquo The woman says she started ringing the police on , but she hung up before getting through to a call handler.Elsewhere over the weekend, Facebook user Scott Brown was disappointed to see rubbish discarded off the Granites Road, near Innerleithen.In his video posted on Sunday morning, he urged residents to pick up any litter they have dropped after social gatherings.He said: ldquoWe want you guys to come and enjoy the countryside and share it with us, butyoursquore going to be doing it, at least be responsible and take all your crap with you when yoursquove finished your fun and games.Mr Brownrsquos video racked up thousands of views and hundreds of comments.

title: borders-teachers-return-schools-next-week
story: TEACHERS in the Borders are due toto school next week.Scottish Borders Councilsays some teaching staff will go back from June  to prepare for classes to restart in August.It comes after First Minister Nicola Sturgeon announced that schools can reopen from August .An SBC spokesperson said: "Some teaching staff willto schools on or around  June, during which time very small numbers of pupils may be able to access schools to support transitions and also school leavers."Our priority is the safety of pupils and staff and we are putting in place the necessary arrangements and will continue to provide updates to parents."

title: study-galashiels-among-safest-places-pandemic
story: GALASHIELS is one of the safest places to live in Scotland during the coronavirus pandemic, according to research.Scotianomics, a think tank, has ranked the countrys  council areas based on the risk of transmitting the virus.Of the  wards in the Borders, Galashiels and District is the safest ndash sitting in th place in the table .Scotianomics founding director Gordon MacIntyre-Kemp said: ldquoThis is nothing to do with the number of cases in an area or how well people living in each area have observed the lockdown.ldquoIt is not a map of COVID- cases across Scotland but of the areas most at risk of community infection."In the Borders, Kelso and District is the most at risk ward , according to the study, with Hawick and Hermitage next , followed by Jedburgh and District .The research, led by senior Samuel MacKinnon, was conducted during April and has been submitted to the Scottish Governmentrsquos Advisory Group on Economic Recovery.Mr MacIntyre-Kemp believes the findings help to argue that lockdown should be lted at dferent speeds in dferent locations.He said: ldquoWhat is evident is that, for a wide iety of reasons, the risks y hugely in dferent communities across Scotland.ldquoIn terms of both the economy and health and wellbeing, we believe it makes sense to ease the lockdown according to those regional dferences in risk.ldquoThere has already been a great deal of debate on whether the four nations within the UK should ease restrictions in lockdown, despite the fact that Oban is likely to have a completely dferent risk profile to Tower Hamlets in London.ldquoWhat our research shows is that there are also signicant iations even within Scotland.He added: ldquoAcross the world, other countries, including China, Italy and Germany, responded to the initial threat on a regionalised basis and are now lting lockdown according to regional iations.ldquoOur research suggests this is the most likely way to prevent a second wave and to protect the economy.The research does not factor in actual infection rates or the fatalities recorded in each area, as the researchers say those figures are not yet publicly available in a sufficiently detailed format.Instead, the study is based on existing data for Scotlandrsquos  local authority wards and calculates each arearsquos risk of exposure according to two factors ndash transmission probability and potential for fatalities.Key information includes population density how many older people or those with underlying health conditions live in the area how many people use road and rail travel how easy it is to access local health services and socioeconomic factors, such as the average income of residents in each area.Scotianomics, created in , aims to analyse the Scottish economy in a way that can help policy makers.The Covid- Risk Monitor can be viewed online at www.scotianomics.org  covid-risk-monitor

title: reaction-borders-mum-accuses-teenagers-ignoring-lockdown
story: SHONA Haslam is urging parents to keep track of their children after a claim that some teenagers broke social distancing rules at the weekend.A mum-of-two reported seeing large groups of teenagersbreaching lockdown guidance in Peebles on Friday evening .Now the leader of Scottish Borders Council has warned residents about the risk of causing a ldquosecond spike of coronavirus cases.Mrs Haslam, a Peebles councillor, said: ldquoI would simply ask all parents to make sure that you know where your kids are and who they are with.The updated lockdown guidance, which came into force on May , allows Scots to meet one other household outdoors, as long as the gathering contains no more than eight people in total and everyone remains two metres apart.The witness account from Friday described several large groups of teenagers gathering along the river, apparently in breach of the lsquoone other householdrsquo instruction ndash as well as the two-metre rule.Asked to comment on the episode, Mrs Haslam said: ldquoUnfortunately over the weekend a small number of young people were being disruptive.ldquoI have spoken to the police and they have increased patrols over the weekend and these will continue.ldquoI would simply ask all parents to make sure that you know where your kids are and who they are with.ldquoIt is really hard for teenagers not seeing their friends for such a long time, but this virus could easily resurge and we all have to stay alert to ensure that we donrsquot get a second spike.Mrs Haslam added: ldquoThe vast majority of our young people are fantastic, sticking by the rules and engaging with their schools and communities.ldquoWe must never fall into the trap of tarring them all with the same brush.ldquoSo [a] massive shout out to all of our young people who are continuing their learning through their schools, and helping contain this virus.Mrs Haslamrsquos Tweeddale East colleague Robin Tatler recommended that constituents phone the police on they spot people breaking lockdown rules.Mr Tatler said: ldquoIt is disappointing to hear that some people in Peebles are acting in an irresponsible way during this dficult time especially as most are not.ldquoIt is important that anyone who witnesses behaviour like this or any other anti-social behaviour should report this using the  number.ldquoThere were a iety of incidents in the town over the past weekend, and I will be asking the Community Action Teams to respond to this.Police Scotlandrsquos Chief Constable Iain Livingstone said on Friday that officers would encourage compliance with the updated lockdown guidance.He said: "We are asking people to take personal responsibility to do the right thing and remember the purpose of these measures is to aid the collective effort to protect the NHS and save lives by preventing the virus from spreading.He added: "We want people to enjoy our outdoor spaces safely and our officers will be robustly tackling crime and anti-social behaviour in our communities."

title: borders-mp-job-losses-jedburgh-devastating-economy
story: BORDERS MP John Lamont says news of possible job losses at a Jedburgh factory is ldquodevastating for the local economy.Coat hanger manufacturer Mainetti announced todaythat up to  workers are at risk of redundancy.Mr Lamont said: ldquoThese job losses in Jedburgh are yet more devastating news for the Borders economy.Mainetti, which is moving operations to Wales, says it intends to sell its Oxnam Road factory to Borders firm Emtelle.Mr Lamont ndash the Conservative representative for Berwickshire, Roxburgh and Selkirk ndash said the economic impact of coronavirus is likely to be ldquosignicant.Reflecting on the Mainetti announcement, he added: ldquoThis will be extremely dficult news for the workers and their families particularly at a time when there is so much uncertainty.ldquoIt is important that the PACE redundancy support is put in place by Scottish Borders Council and the Scottish Government as quickly as possible to give everyone affected all the help they need.ldquoI am also happy to assist any employees affected by this news.ldquoJedburgh urgently needs a stimulus package to boost economic growth in the area to allow it to recover from these signicant job lossesldquoI will be contacting the Scottish Government, the local council and the South of Scotland Economic Partnership to discuss how we can help the town and the wider Borders economy to recover after the impact of the coronavirus.Meanwhile, MSP Rachael Hamilton, also of the Conservatives, said she was very upset to learn about the threat to jobs in Jedburgh.The Holyrood member for Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire said: ldquoI am devastated to hear of more damaging job cuts.ldquoThe financial impact will hit hard in a fragile rural area like the Borders.ldquoThe Scottish Government must plan now for an economic recovery and try to mitigate further job losses and ensure the people of the Borders can find alternative work opportunities.ldquoI am here to help as best I can, please do get in contactyou, a family member or a relative is affected.Jedburgh councillor Scott Hamilton said: ldquoThe people and businesses of Jedburgh are resilient but it is clear that we are not going to be immune to the impact of coronavirus on our economy.ldquoMainetti has provided good jobs for the people in this area so it will be a real shame to see their manufacturing plant shut.ldquoJedburgh will no doubt recover, but it is important that we get the help we need to be able to attract investment in our town to help economic growth in the future.

title: i-worry-seizure-even-though-medicine-works
story: A GALASHIELS schoolgirl with epilepsy has made a video to teach people about the condition.Lucy Millar gets seizures lasting up to  seconds due to childhood absence epilepsy .Now the nine-year-old wants to teach people how to react when someone has a seizure.Her father Bruce said he felt "pretty emotional" as his daughter crafted a YouTube video, which has gone on to achieve more than , views."Right from the start she wanted to reach as many people as possible to teach them about CAE ," said Mr Millar, whose daughter was diagnosed a year ago.Lucy said: "I feel more OK about it [CAE] because I know more about epilepsy now."Sometimes I worry that Ill have a seizure even though I know my medicine works."I dont think many people know there are dferent types of epilepsy andmore people know about it then its better for epileptics."I would like to teach people what to dosomeone they know has an absence seizure to make sure they are safe."Also to help people spot absence seizures with their children."This newspaper asked Mr Millar what advice he would give parents whose children have epilepsy.He said: "Take a deep breath ndash you might feel like youve been hit by a train, but theres a good chance your child is braver than you realise."He also recommended joining support groups and letting children with epilepsy socialise together.To watch Lucys video, you can click this link.

title: bike-library-helps-key-workers-borders
story: A "BIKE library" has been launched to help key workers during the coronavirus pandemic.Just Cycle and Momentum Scottish Borders, the employability service, started the project at the Tweedbank Craft Centre in March.Key workers have been encouraged to borrow bikes to help them travel to work.Peebles carer Amy, of Walkerburn, said she is "so grateful" for the scheme.She said: "I am much less anxious now as I have a better option to get to work and itrsquos a lot more manageable."I know other carers who would benefit from this and have texted my friend, who is also worried about getting to and from work, to let her know about the bikes."Just Cycle usually gets its recycled bikes from recycling centres around the Borders, but it struggled when the sites were closed.However, the project has been able to meet demand thanks to the kindness of Borders residents.Just Cycle manager Deborah Crozier said: "We put out a call on our Facebook page, requesting donations of unwanted bikes."As always, the Borders community answered our call, donating a further  bicycles."Cycling UK also got in touch to let us know about the Big Bike Revival for Key Workers fund that would allow us to restore more bikes to further support the bike library."We got the funding, and our socially distanced volunteer mechanics ndash Stephen, Andy and Grant ndash have been working flat out to restore, repair and recycle more bicycles."Momentum Scottish Borders Gillian Ormiston said the group received help from cycling product supplier Muc Off.The company provided antibacterial spray and cleaning products to ensure health and safety standards were upheld.Ms Ormiston said: "In my role, it was in my best interests to look at ways to contribute to keeping the Borders on the move."Sustaining and maintaining employment for the Scottish Borders is vital, even more so through this pandemic, to enable key workers to remain focused and on the move, and to support their everyday needs."For more information, visit the Just Cycle Facebook page at: www.facebook justcycle

title: borders-university-staff-make-ppe-key-workers
story: UNIVERSITY staff have made  sets of protective clothing for key workers.Staff at the Heriot-Watt campus, Galashiels, have been sewing scrubs since mid-May.Volunteer Jane Robertson said: "We are very happy to help and feel its our moral obligation to do so."The School of Design and Textiles, which has been using its own stock, plans to make  more sets of scrub.Head of school Fiona Waldron said: "Our staff who have come forward to volunteer have been a great inspiration and they are working hard, in social distancing conditions, to make as many scrubs as they can.ldquoIn these unprecedented timeswe can help even a few, then its worth it.The scrubs are made from  per cent cotton and can also be used after the pandemic, according to the university.The mini workshop was set up by four staff volunteers, who drew up the scrub designs.Ms Robertson said: ldquoWe have been joking that these will be the best-made scrubs in the country, as we are all finding it dficult to let the quality slip in order to sew them faster!The Heriot-Watt team has also been asked to make , cotton face masks for care homes.

title: blackout-tuesday-happening-can-get-involved
story: George Floyd ndash an African-American man ndash was handcuffed and lying face down on a city street as white American Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin kneeled on the right side of his neck on May .Chauvinrsquos knee remained there for eight minutes and  seconds, despite Floydrsquos repeated pleas of ldquoI canrsquot breathe ndash two minutes and  seconds of that time occurred after Floyd became unresponsive. He died in custody.The fallout has been far reaching, with dramatic clashes between protesters and police forces in many American cities over the past week.Demonstrations have alsobeen seen in countries across the world, despite much of the planet still under some form of lockdown from coronavirus.Today ndashTuesday,June  ndashmarks#BlackoutTuesday, a day when you will likely notice many of your favourite artists, websites and media outlets going dark across Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.Herersquos everything you need to know:What is #BlackoutTuesday Itrsquos hard to pinpoint exactly where the idea for#BlackoutTuesday comes from, but many are crediting music executivesJamila Thomas and Brianna Agyemang with getting the ball rolling with their#theshowmustbepaused initiative.An official websiteexplains that the social media movement is ldquomeant tointentionally disrupt the work weekhellipin observance of the long-standing racism and inequality that exists from the boardroom to the bouled".The music industry is a multi-billion dollar industry built on privilege, and one that has ldquoprofited prominently from black art.ldquoOur mission is to hold the industry at large, including major corporations and their partners who benefit from the efforts, struggles and successes of Black people accountable, says the website.Despite the name lsquoBlackout Tuesdayrsquo being attribute to it,Thomas and Agyemang say: ldquoThis is not just a -hour initiative. We are and will be in this fight for the long haul."What is happening Major musical artistslike the Rolling Stones, Billie Eilish and Quincy Jones havesaid they will observe the day.No hard and fast lsquorulesrsquo have been set on how to show support for the initiative, but it seems asat the very minimum, bands and artists will be modying their social media profiles, changing cover images and display pictures to the colour black.They will also not be posting across social media channelsa number of artists have also cancelled listening parties or fan events.Spoty will add eight minutes and  seconds of silence to selected playlists and podcasts, reflecting theof timeDerek Chauvin an aggressive knee was applied to the side of George Floyds neck.Major record labels like Def Jam, Interscope, Sony Music, Columbia Records, and more are also expected to participate.,params: .pushMusic-based companies such as Live Nation and TikTok have announced that they will support and stand with the black community.Independent bands and labels from across the world will also be lending their support to this most worthy of causes.Who  is taking part While #TheShowMustBePaused and #BlackoutTuesday originated in the music industry, word of the movement has inevitably spread.Now representatives across many dferent industries from entertainment and beyond are lending their support to the cause.Celebrities from the world of film and TV have also vowed to take part, and in America, a number of television networks will go dark for eightminutes and  seconds in honour of Floyd.MTV ldquowill not hold any meetings nor conduct any businesshellip in solidarity with our African American colleagues and loved ones across the country, according toChris McCarthy, president of the ViacomCBS Entertainment  Youth Group.How can I get involved There are a number of ways you can get involved and show your support for #BlackoutTuesdayand the Black Lives Matter movement.Blacking out your social media profiles is a first step, buttheshowmustbepausedlists further suggestions as to how you can make a dference, and enact positive change:If you have been impacted by the recent events, take a break - there is a lot going on and sometimes we all just need a minute. Take that minute...Help the family of George Floyd -www.gofundme f georgefloydFight for Breonna Taylor -justiceforbreonna.org Help the family of Ahmaud Arbery -www.gofundme f i-run-with-maudWant to help protesters  Donate to one or more community bail funds -https:secure.actblue donate bail_funds_george_floydVisit Movement For Black Lives for additional ways you can help the cause -mbl.orgWant to connect with leaders building grass roots campaigns  -www.untilfreedom

title: ibuprofen-tested-treatment-reduce-covid-19-symptom
story: A new trial has been launched to assess whether ibuprofen may hold the key to preventing severe breathing problems in Covid- patients.Experts are assessing whether a special formulation of the cheap drug could help reduce the serious side effect seen among patients infected with the novel coronavirus.It is hoped that the special formulation of the cheap anti-inflammatory drug, to be delivered at a certain point in illness among hospital patients, will reduce severe respiratory illness.This could potentially lead to shorter hospital stays and fewer patients needing help in intensive care units .Mitul Mehta, professor of neuroimaging and psychopharmacology and director of Centre for Innovative Therapeutics at Kings College London, told the PA news agency: ldquoItrsquos a trial for patients with Covid- disease to seegiving them an anti-inflammatory drug ndash a specic form of ibuprofen ndash will reduce the respiratory problems they have.He stressed that the trial was for hospitalised patients ndash not those who have mild or suspected Covid-.Participants will be drawn from those who are hospitalised, but not so ill they are in need of intensive care.ldquoAndwe can reduce their symptoms at that stage we have a number of benefits: we could reduce the amount of time that someone spends in hospital ndash they might recover quicker and go home, thatrsquos obviously a fantastic outcome we also might be reducing the degree of respiratory distress so that it can be managed in the hospital setting, without needing to go to ICU. And that is a fantastic outcome as well.ldquoTheoretically, this treatment, given at this time, should be beneficial.ldquoBut of course, this is based on animal studies. Itrsquos based on case reports, we need to do a trial to show that the evidence actually matches what we expect to happen.Prof Mehta said that animal studies into acute respiratory distress syndrome ndash a symptom of Covid- disease ndash shows that around % of animals with this condition die.But when they are given this special formulation of ibuprofen the survival rates increase to %.vw,vw,px, px"Researchers are assessing whether a specic form of ibuprofen will reduce respiratory problems in Covid- patients ldquoThis is very promising, he said. ldquoBut of course it is an animal study, so we want to translate that really compelling result into humans.The Liberate trial is a joint effort between experts from Guyrsquos and St Thomasrsquo NHS Foundation Trust, Kingrsquos College London and the pharmaceutical organisation the SEEK Group.Half of the patients enrolled in the trial will receive standard care and the other half will receive standard care plus the special ibuprofen formulation.It is hoped that the way the drug has been formulated will reduce potential gastric side effects linked to ibuprofen.Professor Matthew Hotopf, director of the NIHR Maudsley Biomedical Research Centre said: ldquoThis highly innovative therapeutic approach seeks to rapidly advance a potentially important new treatment. If successful, the global public health value of this trial result would be immense given the low cost and availability of this medicine.Early on in the pandemic, there was controversy over the use of ibuprofen after a French health minister advised against the use of it.Scientists in Britain launched a review to assess ties to the drug and Covid-.The Commission on Human Medicinesrsquo expert working group concluded: ldquoThere is currently insufficient evidence to establish a link between use of ibuprofen and susceptibility to contracting Covid- or the worsening of its symptoms..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Ibuprofen to be tested as treatment to reduce Covid- symptom

title: martin-lewis-issues-important-advice-homeowners-mortgage-holidays
story: Martin Lewis has released important advice on mortgages for all homeownersacross the country.The MoneySavingExpertshared informationon three-month mortgage holidays, which follows an update bytheFinancial Conduct Authority .What has Martin said Martin said: "Under the regulators plans, you willhave untilOctober to apply for one, and those who have already had one can extend."Yet interest racks up and it can impact you creditworthiness."My hope is that as these holidays are specically for the short-term financial hit of coronavirus,and as the practice is so widespread, it wont be used by many firms, and where it is it wont tarnish iniduals credit reputation for too long."But theres no real way to know. Most importantly, I dont believe this should stop anyone who needs a mortgage holiday from getting one."If its crucial for cash flow, just do it."Yet for those on the border, who may find it temporarily useful but can cope without it, add this to the fact that interest racks up during the payment holiday and Id err on the side of caution."What have the FCA said Christopher Woolard, interim chief executive at the FCA, said: "Our expectations are clear - anyone who continues to need help should get help from their lender."We expect firms to work with customers on the best options available for them, paying particular attention to the needs of their vulnerable customers, and to provide information on where to access help and advice."Where consumers can afford to restart mortgage payments, it is in their best interests to do so. But where they cant, a range of further support will be available."People who are struggling and have not had a payment holiday will continue to be able to apply until October ."What have UK Finance said Stephen Jones, the CEO of UK Finance, said: "Banks and building societies will continue to help their customers get through the crisis and have a wide range of support available."Anyone with concerns about their financial situation should check with their lender to discuss which form of support would be the best choice for them."

title: services-sector-remains-severe-downturn-contracts-slower-pace
story: Activity in the UKrsquos all-important services sector contracted at a slower pace in May but remained under severe pressure despite some lockdown restrictions easing, according to a report.The closely-watched IHS Markit CIPS Services purchasing managersrsquo indexrose to  last month from an all-time low of . in April, but the rate of decline in output was still the fastest since records began in .A score above  means the sector ndash the biggest in the UK economy ndash is growing but anything below  means it is shrinking.The reading was slightly better than feared and better than the earlier so-called flash PMI estimate, but gives an all-sector composite reading of  ndash signalling another clf-edge plunge in the wider economy last month.The report said that while the gradual reopening of some sectors, in particular construction, helped boost client demand, many firms have had to remain shut amid the lockdown and consumer-facing businesses are among the hardest hit.Tim Moore, economics director at survey compiler IHS Markit, said: ldquoThe Covid- pandemic continued to have a severe impact on UK service sector activity in May, despite a boost in some areas from the gradual easing of lockdown measures.He added: ldquoService providers recorded another modest improvement in their business expectations from the low point seen in March, with some hopeful that the reopening of clientsrsquo business operations would start to boost activity in the coming months.ldquoHowever, customer-facing businesses continue to report extreme levels of concern about their near-term prospects, with efforts to adapt to social distancing measures set to hold back capacity and generate a sharp increase in costs..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Services sector remains in  usevere u downturn but contracts at slower pace

title: dig-ponds-countryside-boost-rare-wetland-plants-experts-urge
story: Digging ponds in the countryside can deliver ldquounprecedented gains for nature, experts said after a study showed they signicantly boosted rare plants.A nine-year project found that creating just  clean water ponds across  square kilometresof farmland increased the number of wetland plant species by more than a quarter .The number of regionally rare plants almost trebled, with an increase of %, while species that had gone extinct in the local area ed, the research found.The study, published recently in the journal Biological Conservation, tested a range of measures for improving freshwater habitat and wildle in the countryside in three catchment areas in Leicestershire." srcset"https:content.assets.pressassociation.io    acacc-bdbc-bd--cefb.jpg w, https:content.assets.pressassociation.io    acacc-bdbc-bd--cefb.jpg w w, https:content.assets.pressassociation.io    acacc-bdbc-bd--cefb.jpg w w, https:content.assets.pressassociation.io    acacc-bdbc-bd--cefb.jpg w w" sizes" vw,vw,px, px"Ponds had much better results for plant ersity than other measures These included putting woody debris in streams, damming up ditches to create pools that slowed run-off and building interception ponds to filter out nutrients and other pollutants.The project also created clean water ponds, focusing on digging them in low intensity pasture, scrub or woodland where they would fill up with clean water and avoid pollution running off from agriculture or roads.In the absence of any measures the number of wetland plant species would have declined by % over the nine years of the project, the study said." srcset"https:content.assets.pressassociation.io    cd-cd-a--cfdac.jpg w, https:content.assets.pressassociation.io    cd-cd-a--cfdac.jpg w w, https:content.assets.pressassociation.io    cd-cd-a--cfdac.jpg w w, https:content.assets.pressassociation.io    cd-cd-a--cfdac.jpg w w" sizes" vw,vw,px, px"Ponds in low intensity pasture, scrub and woodland that does not get run-off from roads or farming were best for plant le The experts said the clean water ponds were many times more effective than the other measures tested out.They were also one of the cheapest interventions, costing just pound,-pound, each to dig, and helped bring back rare species such as marsh arrowgrass, bristle club-rush and marersquos tail.Lead author Penny Williams, from Freshwater Habitats Trust, said: ldquoThe gains we saw are unprecedented for freshwater and are, by a long way, the largest recorded improvements in freshwater ersity seen from adding land management measures to countryside landscapes.ldquoOur previous work had already shown that ponds were a secret treasure in the British countryside ndash with a value out of proportion to their tiny size ndash however the scale of benefits from adding new ponds took all of us by surprise.Dr Jeremy Biggs, Freshwater Habitats Trust director, said the study proved it was possible to increase freshwater ersity signicantly at a regional scale.ldquoThis is such an important result: freshwater bioersity is under threat both across the UK and the globe.ldquoClimate change will wreak even more havoc in future years and up to now we have found very few ways to combat losses and make the countryside more resilient.The project team say creating clean water ponds speci#cally targeted to boost nature could help stem and even reverse the ongoing declines in freshwater plant species in agricultural landscapes.The results come from the Water Friendly Farming project by the Freshwater Habitats Trust, Game and Wildle Conservation Trust, the University of York, the Environment Agency and landowners in three Leicestershire catchments..push,i[r].l*new title: london-city-reopen-commercial-flights-end-june
story: Commercial flights willto London City Airport by the end of June.The airport announced that domestic routes will be the first to resume.International flights will restart early next month but the timing ldquomay depend on the proposed quarantine of passengers arriving into the UK, according to a statement.London Cityrsquos runway has been closed to commercial and private flights since March  due to travel restrictions and the collapse in demand caused by the coronavirus pandemic.It is normally the UKrsquos th busiest airport, handling . million passengers last year.Its location close to the capitalrsquos financial district makes it particularly popular with business travellers.The airport said in a statement it will introduce a series of measures to ldquoprovide reassurance to passengers once it reopens.These include temperature checking technology for arriving and departing passengers, providing staff with face masks and visors, and ldquorigorous cleaning.The airport will survey travellers on its database to get their thoughts on the future flying experience.London City chief executive Robert Sinclair said: ldquoWhen our doors reopen again shortly, our ambition is to provide the best airport experience in the UK to our passengers by ensuring we follow industry guidance to the letter and by maintaining our reputation as the quickest London airport to get to and through.ldquoWhile there are many challenges ahead for the UK aviation industry, it is our hope that by outlining the steps we are taking to make the airport safe, and by incorporating the views of our regular travellers into our plans, we will give people the confidence to fly from our airport to destinations across the UK and Europe..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: London City to reopen for commercial flights by end of June

title: north-berwick-teen-signs-edinburgh-rugby
story: Ben Muncaster, from North Berwick, was one of three signings completed by the capital side last Friday.The back-row moves from Leicester Tigers, where he spent four years as part of the Premiership sidersquos academy.The -year-old said: ldquoIrsquom extremely excited to be joining this club.ldquoI grew up in North Berwick and have always loved Edinburgh as a city, so to be joining the professional rugby team is a dream come true.And he added: ldquoEdinburgh are obviously a very strong team with a great culture.ldquoThey have some exceptional players that I have looked up to for many years.ldquoIrsquoll hopefully try and learn from them as much as I can, certainly in the back row.ldquoIt is such an honour to have been given an opportunity like this, I am very grateful for it, and I want to make the absolute most of it.The teenager, who attended Loretto School, Musselburgh, joins Edinburgh alongside fellow Scotland age-grade players Nathan Chamberlain, who moves from Bristol Bears, and Dan Gamble, who has signed from Heriotrsquos Rugby.Richard Cockerill, head coach at Edinburgh Rugby, was pleased to sign the trio.He said: ldquoItrsquos hugely important that we continue to develop and nurture young Scottish talent, so itrsquos brilliant that wersquove been able to sign three very impressive age-grade players.ldquoBen has come through the ranks at Leicester and has consistently improved his game year after year.ldquoHe will only get better being involved and training with a talented back-row group here at Edinburgh.Muncaster has previously represented Scotland during the under-s Six Nations.Previously speaking to the Leicester Tigers website, he said: ldquoI lived near my local club when I was a kid and so itrsquos no surprise I started playing when I was about four or five.ldquoMy dad enjoys watching but never really played ndash I joined my local rugby club and loved every minute of it.

title: blow-musselburgh-racing-hopes
story: Bosses at the East Lothian track had hoped to hold races behind closed doors on Saturday, June , as the industry looks to restart under restrictions.Groundstaff at thetownrsquos award-winning racecourse, who have been furloughed, were expected to temporarily resume work this month to prepare the track for the anticipated fixture.And East Lothian MP Kenny Macaskill added his voice to a letter to Scottish sports minister Joe FitzPatrick, MSP, urging him to allow Scotlands racecourse to host fixtures as soon as possible.Bill Farnsworth, general manager, was due on Monday to bring a report to MRACwhich oversees course governance, setting out hopes of a restart in early June.However, the BHA released its provisional fixture list for the restart yesterdayand all the racing proposed is in England.The BHA said thatGovernment restrictions eased at the end of the month, it intended to start behind-closed-door racing at Newcastle on June  with  meetings at seven tracks planned for the first eight days of racing.After a single meeting on June  there will be at least two meetings each day with three ndash one each in the north, south and midlands ndash scheduled from Saturday June  to Monday June  inclusive.There will be no regional restrictions on runners competing at any meetings.Mr Farnsworth had hoped Musselburgh would be allowed to take part in the behind closed doors fixtures in June after pointing out how the industry was ready to go.He said: ldquoIf horseracing resumes in June, we hope to stage Musselburghrsquos scheduled fixture on Saturday,June  butthe advice is that June is too early to stage horseracing in Scotland, we will wait until for the appropriate time and for the greenlight from the UK and Scottish Governments.Horse-racing ed in France this week giving hope to trainers that Britain will not be far behind.A joint letter to Scottish Sports Minister Joe Fitzpatrick, MSP, from East Lothian MP Kenny MacAskill and MPs Allan Dorans, Angela Crawley and Pete Wishart, who represent racecourses in Hanmilton, Ayr and Perth urges a quick restart to racing when safe to do so.It says: ldquoRacing finds itself in a unique position compared to other Scottish sports in that our equine athletes, cherished so highly by those in the industry, have remained in training during thepandemic and will therefore be able to come back on shorter notice than the human athletes inother sports.ldquoWhen it is safe to do so, ato racing is the best way of getting the economic cogs of theindustry turning once more, and kickstart the benefits to the Scottish economy that horseracingbrings, even in a behind closed doors environment.ldquoTherefore, we ask that you please accelerateyour talks with Scottish racing to ensure that a risk managedcan take place as soon aspossible and that ato racing behind closed doors in Scotland does not get unduly delayedcompared to the rest of the United Kingdom.

title: tributes-paid-british-legion-loses-two-members
story: Chairman of the branch Edward OrsquoConnor died on May , at Tranent Care Home, where he was being cared for after suffering a minor stroke.Mr OrsquoConnor, , was described by branch secretary Andrew Davie as an active member who was always involved in ious s in the club, often officiating in sports and competitions such as golf, bowling, fishing, dominoes and darts.Mr Davie said Mr OrsquoConnor had also been the first to join a recently created area of the British Legion, Edinburgh, Lothians and Borders. He carried out his duties as chairman all over Scotland representing the new area.Mr Davie said: ldquoHe will be missed by all the members, as he was always in the club. His long service in the RAF, home and abroad will be remembered.Mr OrsquoConnor leaves one daughter, Sharon.The branch also lost management committee member Alistair Marshall in March.Mr Marshall was well known for collecting thousands of pounds for Poppyscotland and acting as standard bearer for the Royal British Legionat ceremonial events.Mr Marshall, who was , served in the Royal Engineers.Mr Davie said: ldquoAlistair was involved in doing many things when on the committee. As a dedicated doorman at the weekend he made sure everybody behaved themselves. At other events he was a collector for Poppyscotland, especially during Armistice Remembrance, raising many thousands of pounds.ldquoHe was also a standard bearer, carrying out his duties at ceremonial events for RBL and at the passing away of our many comrades, at the graveside and crematoriums.ldquoTo his we Sylvia and stepchildren Karen and Bob, we send our deepest sympathy. He will be sadly missed by all his comrades.

title: seamstress-schoolgirl-sews-masks-ve-day-bunting
story: Niamh McMath, , a primary six pupil at Cockenzie Primary School, is making the masks using a sewing machine she received for Christmas one year, after completing sewing classes.Mum Marie, who lives with Niamh on North Seton Park, said: ldquoShe is making them herself as she got sewing lessons. She just loved them and then got a sewing machine for Christmas.ldquoShersquos really good at it and has made lots of things since the schools have been off shersquos made me a peg bag and a little pouch that can go around my wrist to store my phone in when Irsquom out walking the dog.ldquoI donrsquot know how she does it all.Niamhrsquos younger sister Orla helps by cutting the material and preparing it for production.The material she is using to make them was bought for her by friends and family when she received her sewing machine.A lack of elastic means Niamh is using string, which she finger-knits to make the loops that secure the mask around the wearerrsquos ears.Marie said: ldquoShe saw something in the news about people starting to making their own masks and also the schools making things like visors and she was inspired by that and thought she could make them herself.Niamh sourced a pattern she could refer to and, as there is no printer in the house, drew out the pattern herself.Marie said: ldquoShe made the first one all by herself and when she knew the process enough she explained it to my younger daughter.In about two weeks, Niamh has made roughly  masks, handing them out to friends and family who live nearby.Marie said: ldquoShersquos really talented at it.ldquoA couple of people we have given them to have offered some money but we said to donate it to charity.ldquoItrsquos a challenge to fit things in around school work.ldquoShe made bunting for the front of the house for VE Day, so that took up a bit of time, but she is back to making masks as usual.

title: shielding-runner-takes-garden-half-marathon
story: Stephen Ferguson, , who has asthma, decided to undertake the challenge as he is currently lsquoshieldingrsquo for  weeks after receiving advice from the NHS amidst the Covid- pandemic.He is no stranger to half marathons, having completed three in the past ndash Glentress Trail, Edinburgh and, most recently, Stirling.This time round he is planning to take his treadmill outside on June , and hopes to finish his lsquogardenrsquo half marathon ndash . miles ndash in about two hours.He might even attempt the full marathon distance of . miles in four hourshe can raise enough money for First Step, which celebrates its th anniversary this year.Mr Ferguson, who works with the Royal Bank of Scotland in Haddington, lives on Musselburghrsquos Galt Crescent, near First Step in Galt Avenue, and was inspired to take on the fundraising challenge as his three-year-old son Cormac enjoys attending its nursery.He said: ldquoMy we and son also attended baby classes there, so, from when he was a newborn, he has been involved with First Step.ldquoAll the staff there are amazing and it is more like a family than a nursery. My son gets so excited about going there on a daily basis to see his friends and teachers.ldquoI have seen first hand what First Step does for the community. They are a vital asset to Musselburgh and the surrounding areas.Originally from Omagh in Northern Ireland, Mr Ferguson has lived in Scotland since October , and married his we Louise last October.He also has a step daughter, Aaliyah, who is approaching her th birthday.He said: ldquoAt the moment I am shielding for  weeks, as advised to by the NHS.ldquoI felt this would be a good opportunity to do something worthwhile and raise some money for charity. I know a lot of smaller charities may be struggling now so itrsquos a no brainer really.His past half marathons have raised pound for Asthma UK, a charity close to his heart, and pound for Marie Curie because of the care his late aunt received from its nurses.He is being helped with his training by Junior Burton of JB Combat Bootcamp, Wallyford.Mr Ferguson explained: ldquoJunior Burton and JB Combat Bootcamp have supported me through all these events and helped me improve my quality of le through my fitness, which has improved my asthma undoubtedly.ldquoHe has set me up with an online training plan and has given me extra work to do to help with my marathon training.ldquoI have attended Juniorrsquos bootcamp for around five years now.Mr Ferguson has set a fundraising target of pound, adding: ldquoI would love to smash that and raise at least pound,.First Step was set up in  by a group of local parents who wanted somewhere safe and comfortable where they could meet and their children could play.The initiative has developed its services to meet local needs while continuing to be managed by a community-led management committee and employing a staff team to support local families.To donate to Mr Fergusonrsquos challenge, go to justgiving crowdfunding stephen-ferguson-

title: day-centre-receives-holyrood-recognition
story: Harlawhill Day Centrersquos efforts during the coronavirus pandemic were highlighted by the countyrsquos MSP, Iain Gray.The facility had to close its doors on March  due to the global pandemic but Mr Gray felt it was important to recognise the efforts being made by staff and volunteers.The centre, on the townrsquos East Loan, has continued to offer a range of support to members during the pandemic, including organising socially distanced street celebrations outside membersrsquo homes to help mark VE Day and delivering special afternoon tea packages and other food and treats to help keep their spirits up during lockdown.Mr Gray, who lodged a motion at Holyrood highlighting the facility, told the Courier: ldquoHarlawhill Day Centre has always been a special place, very much at the heart of the community in Prestonpans.ldquoIt was a very sad day when it had to close its doors to members back in March. However, the innovative ways they have found to stay connected to service users really exemplies the strong sense of community that has been so evident across East Lothian during the pandemic.ldquoThe staff and volunteers at Harlawhill have gone to great s to maintain the superb care and support they give to members and I am pleased to be able to mark their dedication, as well as that of other local day centres, at Holyrood and thank them for everything they have continued to do to help people over the past few weeks.The motion at Scottish Parliament included the lines: ldquoThat the Parliament commends everyone at the Harlawhill Day Centre in Prestonpans for their dedication in continuing to care for service users, despite having to close the facility during the COVID- lockdown...ldquo...And thanks the staff and volunteers at Harlawhill, and all of East Lothianrsquos other day centres, for the care and support that they are continuing to provide to older people during the Covid- pandemic.

title: musselburgh-racecourse-cancels-summer-fixtures
story: It announced earlier this afternoon that all races scheduled for July and August are now cancelled due to "ongoing conditions surrounding Covid-".Anyone who purchased a ticket will be contacted shortly to arrange a refund.Those who purchased tickets in person, by phone or by email are asked to contact musselburghracecourse@eastlothian.gov.uk

title: residents-urged-no-longer-roam-free-west-links
story: While many town residents have used the famous course for exercise, including ball games and cycling, club general manager Elaine McBride has requested that this no longer happens, allowing the club to ldquoreclaim the course and use it for what it was intended for.A post on the clubrsquos Facebook page said: ldquoWe welcome the news that golf will resume very shortly.ldquoDue to this, it means that the golf course will no longer be available for you to roam freely and enjoy as you have for the past nine weeks. You will, of course, be able to access the beach via the designated crossing points.ldquoFrom everyone here at the West Links we hope you have enjoyed your time using the West Links and we would like to thank you for looking after it during these dficult times.ldquoWe look forward to welcoming our members back to play golf.Elaine added that those at the club were ldquovery mindful of associated health and safety issues when golfers ed to play on the course.She said: ldquoWe are delighted to hear about the resumption of golf, albeit with a number of restrictions.ldquoWe are looking forward to welcoming our members back onto the West Links and hope that, over the forthcoming weeks, we can all adapt our behaviours to our new normal.Having walked the course regularly during lockdown to check its condition, she added: ldquoGiven the limited resources and the fact that we were only able to carry out essential maintenance, the course is in good shape to welcome members back.Members at the townrsquos Glen Golf Club cannot wait to get back onto the fairways, says the clubrsquos marketing convenor Mick Hunter.He told the Courier that tee times for tomorrow , which were available from am-pm, have been fully booked.Mick said: ldquoItrsquos been frustrating for us but our members have been supportive.ldquoWe had a number of visitors booked in over the last few weeks which we have had to cancel.ldquoUnquestionably, golfers are chomping at the bit to get back on the golf course, which will hopefully be later this week.ldquoWe have introduced new guidelines to make sure we keep our golfers safe and our staff safe as well.Members can play with a guest but golfers are asked: not to remove or touch the flagstick to stay at least two metres away from their playing partner when walking between shots and not to shake hands, lsquobumprsquo elbows or lsquohigh fiversquo their partner.

title: walkers-told-not-feed-wild-ponies
story: It comes after reports were made that people are feeding the ponies, who are wild and eat the grass and flowers at both locations.A Countryside Rangers statement said: ldquoItrsquos essential that the public do not feed them.ldquoWe need them to graze the Laws.A council spokesperson added: ldquoAlthough there have been signs at both Laws in place for a number of years advising visitors not to feed the ponies, we have had to issue reminders via social media as it appears people have been visiting and feeding the ponies.The spokesperson added that the ponies did not need extra feeding, as the terrain they live on provides all their essential food.The ponies were brought to the Laws to reduce grass vegetation and allow other plants to grow through.The council spokesperson also said that, by feeding the ponies, visitors would change the animalsrsquo behaviour, meaning they would come to expect to be fed.This could cause concern to other walkers who might be scared of horses.

title: three-drivers-stopped-without-insurance-haddington
story: A report of a number of incidents was sent to the townrsquos community council ahead of their postponed May meeting.The community council has not met since March.However, Police Constable Charlie Duncan highlighted recent incidents in the town in his e-mailed report.One of those saw a vehicle stopped on Briery Bank on May .The driver was found to be uninsured and was reported to the Procurator Fiscal.Meanwhile, two other drivers were stopped in the town and found to be without insurance.On April , a vehicle was stopped on Sidegate while a second was stopped on Florabank Road on April .Both drivers were given fixed penalty tickets.

title: storybook-campaign-bids-bring-fun-families
story: East Lothian Play Associationhas been working with Wallyford Community Centre and the First Step Community Project in Musselburgh to develop the initiative.Susan Humble, the associationrsquos loose parts play development officer, said: ldquoThe book, called lsquoYou and Mersquo, is aimed at young children and adults to enjoy together and get ideas of ways to use items around the house.ldquoItrsquos a really important time to get resources to families at home and we are also fundraising to provide play packs to accompany the book.ldquoThey will be distributed through school hubs and community networks.Packs would include items for den building and imaginative play, carefully chosen so children use their imagination and creativity.They would have a sensory foil blanket, pegs, bubbles, chalk and peg dolls. The storybook provides inspiration for multiple ways to use these items.Combining items from the play pack with everyday things from around the home, as the story shows, can provide hours of fun while also learning.A parent who has taken part in the project commented: ldquoThe book project idea came from a few sessions of play with mothers and their child children, which involved dferent activities similar to the book.ldquoIt is important to support families through this dficult period as some, like me, are single parents on their own with children, so play is important as it helps your imagination and to develop your skills.ldquoReceiving a storybook and play pack would be so helpful as not everyone has access to play, the right kind of materials or much space at home to play and, with all the right tools, it can help boost how yoursquore feeling as you are lost in play with your imagination ndash something some people donrsquot always get to do or feel comfortable doing.So far, enough funds have been raised for , storybooks to be distributed across East Lothian.For information on the project and to donate, visit www.crowdfunder helping-families-play-every-day-covid-.During the lockdown, ELPA has also posted daily play challenges on Facebook at facebook elpaplayrangersSusan said: ldquoPlay is crucial to childrenrsquos mental health and wellbeing and can help us stay physically active while having fun.

title: golden-couple-toast-marriage-milestone-lockdown
story: John and Jean Hamilton marked  years of married bliss last Saturday at their home in Prestonpans.However, lockdown restrictions meant the couple were not able to share the day with their two sons or seven grandchildren.John, , and Jean, , met at the Labour Club in Prestonpans in , before tying the knot at Prestonpans Registry Office in May the following year.They have two sons, David, , and Andrew, .John, originally of Prestonpans, worked as a telephone engineer with BT, while Jean, who is from Cockenzie and Port Seton, worked as a secretary before going on to work at Muirfield Care Home.The couple advised that sharing and facing everything together was the secret to their y marriage, with the couple hoping to have a celebratory meal with their family once the restrictions are lted.In the meantime, Jean said there was not much to do to mark the occasion but joked about doing a waltz in the living room with Johnrsquos zimmer.Their family said: ldquoHappy th wedding anniversary! Love Andrew, Deborah, Nicole, Calum and Rebecca.

title: haddstock-home-brings-music-festival-peoples-homes
story: Haddstock was due to take place in Haddington town centre this weekend.However, with the event, which was ing after a yearrsquos break, pushed back to September due to the virus, the organisers have come up with Haddstock at Home.Rebecca Dover said: ldquoMay  and  were the original dates of the festival.ldquoThen we learnt of the pandemic and we were devastated and agreed to postpone Haddstock in its real festival sense until September.ldquoThe new dates for in the town are September  and .ldquoWe thought, in the meantime, would it not be great to showcase our artists, musicians, performers and facilitators to have a weekend of posts, live music, art and music activities ldquoThen people can enjoy a festival atmosphere in their own homes or gardens.She added: ldquoIt is not a replacement for the real festival but something fun for lockdown.The festival launched in  and was headlined by Aberfeldy, who previously supported REM at Loch Lomond.Two-thousand people packed Haddington, with pubs, cafes and other venues throughout the town hosting a number of musicians.The festivalrsquos success saw the eventthe following year, with a similar number of people in attendance.Organisers took a break last year but had lined up more than  acts for the festival this year.Now, the team behind the event are organising Haddstock at Home.Rebecca said: ldquoSo many families in Haddington enjoy Haddstock.ldquoHaddstock at Home will be on Facebook and our website HaddstockldquoIt is video based, so there will be videos from all of our facilitators and performers.ldquoIt will be available throughout the weekend and afterwards so people can still access it in their own time.Plans also continue to be in place for the rearranged Haddstock .Family and cultural events, authors and storytelling, were all part of the original plans.Rebecca was hopeful coronavirus-related restrictions could be lted before the rearranged festival takes place.She was hopeful Haddstock  could benefit the townrsquos economy, which has been hit by the lockdown restrictions.

title: marie-curie-blown-away-donation
story: Cancer support group Marie Curie received the four-figure sum from Community Windpower and BeGreen Dunbarrsquos Covid- crisis fund.The donation enables Marie Curie clinical nurse specialists to deliver care to people in their own homes while wearing the PPEthey need to deliver that care safely.Carolyn Snedden, Marie Curie fundraising manager, said: ldquoThis donation is a tremendous boost for us and will make such a dference to families at this time.Diane Wood, community benefits director at Community Windpower, which operates the Aikengall Community Windfarms, near Innerwick, said: ldquoMarie Curie does amazing work with people in our local communities and wersquore pleased to help the nurse specialists provide their care safely.

title: big-drive-adopt-street-keep-clean
story: The lsquoAdopt a Streetrsquo campaign, launched by the environmental group Love Musselburgh, has been gathering momentum with a band of volunteers offering to keep streets, parks and beaches rubbish free.Melanie Roccio, of Love Musselburgh, said those involved are given litter-picking sticks and clean up their lsquoadoptedrsquo area whenever they wish.She said: ldquoItrsquos a very casual arrangement: there are no minimum or maximum number of times to pick and no targets to reach. I wanted this to be a zero pressure thing.ldquoDuring the Covid crisis, Irsquove not actively encouraged litter picking but am grateful to those who continue to do so.She urged more volunteers to step forward to lsquoAdopt a Streetrsquo in the future.She said: ldquoThe Covid situation has been devastating. But the sense of community has definitely increased and more people are looking out for each other, whether thatrsquos friends, neighbours or strangers.ldquoTherersquos an openness to talk with and smile at others and a real desire to use small, local businesses that may be struggling at this time."I also love the creativity that has been visible throughout the town in the form of chalk drawings,painted stones and rainbows in windows.She added: ldquoI naively thought there would be less litter during lockdown but it seems that disposable gloves and masks have replaced the usual fast food chain packaging.ldquoAdopting a street is a great way to get out and about, meet people and do something good in the community.ldquoWe have nearly  iniduals, families and businesses signed up now but Irsquod love to see that list continue to grow.ldquoOnce lockdown ends it would be great to know there are even more areas being cared for.Councillor John Williamson said Love Musselburgh were doing a wonderful job encouraging locals to take pride in their community and to help make the town a cleaner, greener place for all.ldquoThe Adopt a Street initiative is a great way of letting people do their bit by taking on as much litter picking in a local street, or part of a street, as they feel able to do, he added.ldquoThey can also adopt a local park or bit of beach as well. Of course there would be no litter problempeople disposed of their litter properly either by taking it home or putting it in a litter bin.Councillor Andy Forrest said: ldquoThere has always been a working partnership between East Lothian Councilrsquos landscape and countryside department and Love Musselburgh.ldquoMelanie Roccio and all the volunteers are really committed. We do anything we can to support them and they support the council.Local residents took to social media to give their views on the campaign: Robin Wallace said: ldquoI joined up because Irsquom fed up of seeing rubbish on our streets. Despite the plastic problem in our ocean, I still find bottles everywhere, even close to bins. So, I wanted to help, evenjust small.Susan Stevens added: ldquoIrsquove adopted Denholm Road which has the path at the back of it and a playpark off it. ldquoThe biggest issue Irsquove had is broken glass which gets smashed in amongst the trees where teenagers sit and all around the power house in the park. Also, litter caught in the bushes at the play area are from recycling boxes.Mel Hindley said online that her family adopted their street and her little boy loved nothing more than going up and down with his litter picker!ldquoWe have a charity based on our little street who bought him a gt to say thanks when he had been doing it a while ndash they hadnrsquot realised that some of their service users were sadly also serial litter droppers and that a five-year-old was cleaning up after them! she wrote.ldquoMy wee one was delighted and it felt like a lovely way of illustrating that good things happen when you do something for others. We think the campaign is a great way to help people take pride in where they live itrsquos just a shame that a minority think itrsquos OK to fly tip and drop rubbish where we live.While Pauline Clark, of Park Drive, Wallyford, said: ldquoThe strip in front of my house seems to attract litter: cans and bottles which are dangerous as some children play in that area. My son quite enjoys the challenge [of tidying it up].To get involved in Adopt a Street go to www.facebook lovemusselburgh

title: key-worker-demonstrating-pedal-power-pegasus-e-bike
story: Lidia Josvai, , a support worker, is getting to work using pedal power thanks to an offer from Play Together on Pedals ndash a cycling programme for children and families which expanded from Edinburgh to East Lothian last month.When coronavirus hit, the group could not run any of its normal rides, drop in sessions or family workshops, so it considered other ways to help people during the lockdown.Along with another Cycling UK project, Edinburgh All Ability Bike Centre, they made all their adult bikes available to key workers to get to and from work without having to use public transport.Lidia, who had not cycled in years, borrowed one of the electric bikes on offer and loves using it so much she has named it Peggy, after Pegasus, the mythical winged horse.Previously, she took the bus for the three-mile journey from her home to work at the Thistle Foundation in Craigmillar, Edinburgh ndash a health and wellbeing charity that supports people living with long-term conditions.Now she is enjoying the fresh air, birdsong and scenery on her half hour journey by bike. When shersquos not at work, Lidia has also been exploring new areas of Musselburgh since moving there three years ago.She said: ldquoI need exercise to help with back pain but I used to just come home from work and watch TV ndash I didnrsquot feel like doing any exercise. Now I canrsquot wait to get on the bike and explore. I love riding on the promenade as it doesnrsquot feel like exercise - itrsquos just fun.The last time Lidia cycled was in Budapest with her children.She added: ldquoThat was  years ago and they are now adults. Riding Peggy has given me my confidence back. She has changed my le.Cycling UKrsquos Angie Kinghorn, who runs Play Together on Pedals in Edinburgh, East Lothian and the Scottish Borders, said: ldquoWersquore delighted that our bikes are being put to good use by local key workers like Lidia. Itrsquos fantastic to hear that shersquos really enjoying cycling and that it has boosted her confidence.ldquoMany people are using cycling as a safe way to get from A to B during the lockdown, while others are finding itrsquos a real boost to their health and wellbeing. When itrsquos safe to do so we look forward to bringing our family cycling project to East Lothian, but, in the meantime, we canrsquot think of a better use for the bikes.Play Together on Pedals, funded by Transport Scotland, is a partnership between Cycling UK, Cycling Scotland and Play Scotland.

title: grans-love-writing-leads-third-novel
story: Olivia McMahon previously taught English as a foreign language and has continued her love of writing into retirement.New novel Remorse is set in a remote village by the sea in the north-west of Ireland.The main characters ndash Oscar, a middle-aged writer from London tormented by a lost love, and Eileen, a -year-old from Belfast on the run from the dissident IRA and a terrible secret ndash become friends.Olivia said: ldquoOscar is thinking of a passionate love affair he had  years previously and was it his fault it ended tragically where is she now and is it too late to start over again ldquoHe sets off for Hungary to try to find her.ldquoEileen is on the run from the dissident IRA and regrets her involvement. Then she thinks of a way she can redeem herself.Eileen initially started as a character in a short story before the plot was developed to create Remorse, which is available on Amazon.Olivia was pleased to say everybody who had read the novel had provided positive feedback.The gran-of-four moved to Dunbar from Aberdeen last year to be closer to her family.Immediately, she joined the Dunbar Writersrsquo Group and has continued her love for writing.Previously, Olivia has had several books of poetry published and two other novels.The first ndash Love As A Foreign Language ndash is based on her experience of teaching English as a foreign language in Paris.The French capital is also the setting for her second novel ndash Rose-tinted Scissors ndash which focuses on an ambitious female hairdresser.Olivia, , said: ldquoWriting is what I feel is the most important thing in my le apart from family.ldquoI would hate not to have writing to do ndash I feel Irsquom aliveI am writing.

title: plans-ambitious-dunbear-park-set-revealed-public
story: DunBear Park has been designed around The DunBear sculpture, which was unveiled last year.The development, which is on land to the rear of the townrsquos Asda store and garden centre, is being proposed by Hallhill Developments Ltd.The site includes retail and leisure units, drive-thru units, a hotel, offices, a nursery, care home and elderly amenity flats, as well as industrial and storage units.The plans also include  low carbon affordable homes for rent, which will be aimed at key workers, such as NHS staff, police and care workers.Representatives from the developer were on hand online to discuss the proposals during last weekrsquos meeting with the townrsquos community council.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the community council, said: ldquoWhat has become clear is the development is very, very much at the concept stage.ldquoIt is actually really refreshing to have an opportunity to be involved in the conversation about development well before it becomes fully resolved.Assurances have been sought that the type of businesses looking to move onto the .-acre site would not be duplicating those already in the town centre, while concerns about traffic accessing and leaving the site were also raised.Philip Mellor, owner of the Dunmuir Hotel and chairman of Dunbar Tradesrsquo Association, was also part of the online meeting.He said: ldquoThe traders certainly support activity in that area as long as it is done in the right mind and we do not end up with two split towns ndash an old town and the new town.Discussions have already taken place with the developer with a view to ensuring there are appropriate signs in place to point people in the direction of the established town centre.Mr Mellor felt integration and infrastructure were key to the development and was pleased to see the idea of a visitor centre included within the plans.Ken Ross, from the developer, encouraged people to view the plans on Wednesday afternoon.He said: ldquoWe are delighted to be putting forward our proposals to the local community for this exciting low carbon development and look forward to its involvement in shaping these proposals.ldquoDunBear Park will assist in creating jobs and delivering much-needed housing for key workers.ldquoIt will also assist in supporting the construction-led recovery from the current crisis.ldquoWe are seeking to deliver is an exemplar development, which not only Dunbar, but East Lothian and Scotland can be proud.ldquoThe support of the community will be crucial in achieving this.To view the proposals, go to www.dunbearpark planning between pm and pm tomorrow .Hard copies of consultation boards and feedback forms can be obtained following the event by writing to DunBear Park, c o Orbit Communications,  Queen Street, Edinburgh EH JE or by phoning   .Feedback can be submitted up to June .

title: grannys-stone-art-bringing-joy-town
story: Linda Donachie, , who lives in the Pinkie area, is leaving the colourful keepsakes all over the town for people to find while they are enjoying their daily exercise.She said: ldquoThey can keep them or leave them for others to find.Mrs Donachie, who retired three years ago after  years as the special needs auxiliary at Macmerry Primary School, said she had always looked at dferent craft and sensory ideas for her work.A mum of two and grandmum of four, she collects stones which catch her eye while out for a daily cycle to Morrisonrsquos Haven near Prestonpans with husband David.Back home, she decorates them with faces, sea creatures, hedgehogs, colourful patterns and flowers before leaving them at ious points in the town, including the sea wall, lagoons and Fisherrow harbour. One with a sad face was left at The Grove where a tree had been felled recently.Lucky finders have taken to social media to express their delight for lsquoLinda Drsquo who signs the stones, and she is overwhelmed by the positive feedback about her fun lockdown initiative.Jamie Wilson, of Levenhall, posted: ldquoWe found a magic painted stone on our garden wall. As much as we would love to keep this special stone we have decided to share the joy it brought us so will be passing it on for others to find. Thanks Linda D.Mrs Donachie said: ldquoI am planning to keep on doing it as I get pleasure out of it and always want to make children smile.She has also left stones for friends and posted some to her sisterrsquos grandchildren in Fe, as she lives in Haddington and canrsquot visit them due to the lockdown.Mrs Donachie and her husband also put their craft skills into action by making fun animals for friends and family out of discarded car parts.

title: daily-lockdown-exercise-inspires-artists-work
story: Andrew Siddall, who lives just off Fisherrow Links, is drawing views around the harbour from photographs he takes while out walking with his children during lockdown.He has turned some of his sketches into prints and is seeking commissions, big or small, to draw peoplersquos houses, special places as commemorative gts or to document particular places of interest for posterity.Mr Siddall teaches drawing and design at Edinburgh Universityrsquos College of Art and spends most of the spring and autumn at the college.He explained: ldquoI use the longer days to get out and about in East Lothianrsquos erse town and landscapes to draw places and capture the spirit of our region through carefully observed hand drawings.One of his favourite subjects throughout the year are the boats and yachts at Fisherrow harbour, and his daily exercise near his home has meant that he can continue to record scenes during the lockdown.He is also backing the current national initiative to support artists during the pandemic ndash called the #artistsupportpledge ndash which was set up by East Sussex artist Matthew Burrows.Any artist offers work up to a maximum value of pound and, when they have made pound, in sales , they commit  per cent of their takings to buy another artistrsquos work within the scheme.The initiative now has more than , posts and has generated an estimated pound million for artists and makers across the globe.After graduating from the Royal College of Art in London in the early s, Mr Siddall worked in architecture and public art for around  years.He said: ldquoI started drawing regularly again just a few years ago as it was something I always loved doing but found increasingly missing in professional le.His work is always based on fine line drawings of places, which then become digitally coloured prints or the foundations for paintings, depending on the time and situation.He exhibits and runs private drawing lessons during the summer months, and has a growing following online.He can often be found on the streets with a small sketchbook doing a daily urban sketch, and joins in with the regular Edinburgh Urban Sketchers meet-ups, where drawing the city from le provides a weekly social and creative chance to visit new places and share drawings.He commented: ldquoThere is always plenty of creative work to do but the current lockdown is a challenge, as much of my work is drawing lsquoon locationrsquo and working with communities through public art projects.Mr Siddall is also part of a group project called the #DaysProjectScotland, which involves artists from across the country creating a small piece of work every day for  days.He said: ldquoWersquore not sure whether wersquoll be able to run an exhibition this year but hopefully, by late August, we might have a little more freedom.ldquoThis year I will be making detailed aerial drawings of buildings through the centre of Edinburgh ndash a project I started last year but havenrsquot been able to get back to.He added: ldquoSimilar to keeping in touch with friends and family, keeping lsquovirtuallyrsquo connected with my artist friends provides a sense of normality and continuity at the moment.ldquoNone of us knows how long the current situation will last and wersquore really missing being out drawing from le but the social aspect of making art is almost as important as the process of drawing itself. The  Days project and the daily walks around Musselburgh will keep me busy.Mr Siddall can be contacted by email via andy@siddalldrawing.To see his work, there are regular posts on Instagram at instagram siddall_drawing or Facebook at facebook siddalldrawing

title: community-kitchen-reaches-tasty-milestone-1-000-meals
